QueryText: QUERY REGARDING VERITIES OF APPLE
Refined KCC Query [HF]: What are the varieties of Apple that can be cultivated?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the varieties of Apple that can be cultivated?
KccAns: red delicious golden delicious mcintosh chaubattia anupam lal ambri
QueryText_normalized: query regarding verities of apple
Primary Answer (Level0): Apple cultivation is primarily possible in higher-altitude areas with a temperate climate. Plant apples in well-drained, loamy soil with good sunlight and ensure proper chilling days (typically 800-1200 hours below 7°C) for optimal flowering and fruit set. The recommended apple varieties are Royal delicious(uniform shape with good market value), Red delicious(has good market demand and require moderate chilling hours), Golden delicious(yellow skinned apple with sweet taste and perform well in cool climate), Jonathon(early mature variety with good taste), and McIntosh(small size apple with attractive colours and perform well in cool climate).
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): The recommended Apple varieties are: Red Delicious (Mid-season variety, good market demand and requires moderate chilling hours), Black Bendavis (commercially popular, have good keeping qualities), Royal Gala(Exotic, dark red, good appearance), Jonathan(spicy, juicy, sweet-tart, storage life 120 days), Red Gold(small to medium-sized, deep red skin, suitable for processing), Gani Gala(fine texture and aromatic flavor, used in salads, sauces), Red Delicious(high market demand), Rich-A-Red(suitable for late season harvest), Golden Delicious (yellow-skinned apple with sweet taste and performs well in cool climate), Granny Smith (green apple, long storage life), and McIntosh (small-sized apple with reddish-pink colour and performs well in cool climate).
Comment (Reviewer1):
Missing All Quantification: The biggest flaw is the lack of numbers. It provides a good list of names but gives no yield potential (e.g., in kg per tree or tonnes per acre), which is the most critical information for a farmer to assess profitability.

Missing Planting Details: The advice is incomplete as it lacks the recommended planting distance (e.g., 5m x 5m for these varieties on a suitable rootstock) and the ideal planting time, which is the dormant winter season (December-January) for temperate fruits in this region.
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): The recommended Apple varieties  are: Red Delicious (Mid-season variety, good market demand and requires moderate chilling hours), Black Bendavis (commercially popular, have good keeping qualities), Royal Gala(Exotic, dark red, good appearance), Jonathan(spicy, juicy, sweet-tart, storage life 120 days), Red Gold(small to medium-sized, deep red skin, suitable for processing), Gani Gala(fine texture and aromatic flavor, used in salads, sauces), Red Delicious(high market demand), Rich-A-Red(suitable for late season harvest), Golden Delicious (yellow-skinned apple with sweet taste and performs well in cool climate), Granny Smith (green apple, long storage life), and McIntosh (small-sized apple with reddish-pink colour and performs well in cool climate).
Comment (Reviewer2):
Varieties listed are correct, but McIntosh and Jonathan are less common in India and need specific chill hours (>1000 h).

POPs for NEH region also recommend Early Shanburry, Amri, and Starking Delicious for local adaptation.

QueryText: how much banana saplings shuold be with mother plant after removal of suckers
Refined KCC Query [HF]: After removing extra suckers, how many saplings should be kept with the Banana mother plant?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: After removing extra suckers, how many saplings should be kept with the Banana mother plant?
QueryText_normalized: how much banana saplings shuold be with mother plant after removal of suckers
Primary Answer (Level0): After flowering,  keep only 1 healthy sucker (daughter plant) mother banana plant. Remove all extra suckers every 45–60 days this helps to reduce competition, avoid overcrowding and save nutrients and water, gives better fruit yield. If more suckers are kept, plants compete for water and nutrients, which reduces fruit size and quality. Keeping one strong sucker ensures good yield in the next season. Select the sucker which is close to the main plant, upright, and has a pointed leaf (sword type). Avoid water-filled suckers or those with broad leaves (water suckers), as they are weak and reduce yield. Use a clean sickle for sucker removal and dip it in bleaching powder solution (20 gram per litre of water) before and after cutting to prevent disease. After removal, apply Carbendazim 50% WP @ 200 gram per acre in 200 litres of water near the base to prevent fungal rot. As Carbendazim 50% WP is under some restriction in that case also you can use as alternatively Glyphosate 41% SL at 2 ml per litre of water directly on the sucker’s cut surface to avoid main plant injury . As a rotation, you can also use Copper Oxychloride 50% WP @ 500 gram per acre in 200 litres of water. For organic farmers, mix Trichoderma viride @ 1 kg with 25 kg compost per acre and apply near the base or you can apply common salt or kerosene on the cut part to dry it out but it can be less effective if you only use it. Always use gloves and avoid spraying on the main plant. This practice helps the main plant grow better, gives a healthy ratoon crop, gives more yield and good profit. For any subsidy or loan help, visit your local Horticulture Office and carry these documents: Aadhaar card, land proof (ROR), recent passport-size photo, and bank passbook copy.

QueryText: asking about arecanut management
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Can you provide guidelines on cultivation and management of Arecanut?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Can you provide guidelines on cultivation and management of Arecanut?
KccAns: answer transfer to agri expert
QueryText_normalized: asking about arecanut management
Primary Answer (Level0): Arecanut farming can give good income if done properly with right variety, spacing, and care.  In Arunachal Pradesh, farmers can grow arecanut in areas with good rainfall and well-drained loamy soil. You can go for high-yielding varieties like Mangala, Sumangala, and Mohitnagar — these give good quality nuts and perform well in this region. Apply compost or FYM @ 10–15 kg per pit before planting and keep the field weed-free in early months. While planting, keep a spacing of 2.7 meter by 2.7 meter. This helps the palm grow properly and gives about 1,370 plants per hectare. Dig pits of 60 cm × 60 cm × 60 cm, fill them with compost and topsoil, and plant during May to July, just before monsoon. Each mature arecanut plant needs 100 gram Nitrogen, 40 gram Phosphorus, and 140 gram Potassium per year. You can apply it in two splits – once before monsoon (May–June, ) and second in (September–October). Also you can add neem cake (500 gram per plant) once a year to improve soil and reduce pests. For spindle bug, use Dimethoate 30% EC 1.5 ml of Dimethoate in 1 liter of water as a drenching spray into the leaf axils and crown of the arecanut palm. For mites you can spray Wettable Sulphur (usually 80% WP or 90% WDG formulation) Mix 2.5-3.0 grams of Wettable Sulphur in 1 liter of water for per acre. If you see yellowing and rotting at the base, it may be foot rot — spray 1% Bordeaux mixture  (1 kg copper sulphate and 1 kg lime in 100 litres water per acre) before monsoon and repeat at 40-day interval around the collar region. also you can do cultural control such as mulching, proper drainage, and intercropping for extra income. Mulching with dry leaves and intercropping with crops like ginger or black pepper can give extra income. Arecanut starts yielding after 5 to 6 years and gives good production for 30 to 35 years. With proper care, farmers can get a steady income every year. Arecanut is a long-term crop, so take care in the early years — once it’s established, it gives benefit for decades.

For mites you can spray Wettable Sulphur (usually 80% WP or 90% WDG formulation) Mix 2.5-3.0 grams of Wettable Sulphur in 1 liter of water for per acre. If you see yellowing and rotting at the base, it may be foot rot — spray 1% Bordeaux mixture  (1 kg copper sulphate and 1 kg lime in 100 litres water per acre) before monsoon and repeat at 40-day interval around the collar region. also you can do cultural control such as mulching, proper drainage, and intercropping for extra income. Mulching with dry leaves and intercropping with crops like ginger or black pepper can give extra income. Arecanut starts yielding after 5 to 6 years and gives good production for 30 to 35 years. With proper care, farmers can get a steady income every year. Arecanut is a long-term crop, so take care in the early years — once it’s established, it gives benefit for decades.

QueryText: ASKING ABOUT THE SEASON OF BRINJALBHINDI
Refined KCC Query [HF]: What is the sowing time of Brinjal and Bhindi (Okra)?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the sowing time of Brinjal and Bhindi (Okra)?
KccAns: advised him to select the season summer season
QueryText_normalized: asking about the season of brinjalbhindi
Primary Answer (Level0): Bhindi (Okra) and Brinjal (Eggplant) are not suitable for the rabi season (November to February) because both are warm-season crops, and the cooler climate slows germination, delays flowering, and increases the risk of frost damage and pest/disease problems. The main sowing season of Brinjal is from July to August, and for a second crop, seeds are sown from March to April, and seedlings are transplanted after that. The ideal time to grow Bhindi (okra) is in spring (February to March) and kharif (June to July) because warm climates and monsoon rainfall support healthy growth, but waterlogging conditions during the rainy season must be avoided.

QueryText: ASKING FOR USE OF BORDOUX MIXTURE
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How should I use Bordeaux mixture?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How should I use Bordeaux mixture?
KccAns: suggested him properly
QueryText_normalized: asking for use of bordoux mixture
Primary Answer (Level0): Bordeaux mixture is a traditional, cost-effective fungicide used to control fungal diseases like blight, leaf spots, anthracnose, and fruit rot in crops such as vegetables, fruits, tea, arecanut, and spices. you can make this Bordeaux mixture by mixing copper sulphate and quick lime in water. For general use, farmers in Arunachal Pradesh can prepare a 1% solution by mixing 1 kg copper sulphate and 1 kg lime in 100 litres of water—this is enough for 1 acre to ensure full coverage. It should always be freshly prepared and used the same day. Bordeaux mixture helps forms a protective layer on plant surfaces, preventing fungal spores from infecting. It is especially useful in humid areas like Arunachal, where fungal diseases spread fast. Always wear gloves and a mask while handling it. Avoid spraying during flowering and never mix it with insecticides in the same tank. To avoid resistance, rotate it with other fungicides like Mancozeb 75% WP (600–800 gram per acre) or Copper Oxychloride 50% WP (600 gram per acre) in 200 to 400 liters of water. Though Bordeaux is also suitable for organic farming, it must be used only when disease risk is high and handled with care.

QueryText: sudi doma(brown plant hopper)
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Brown Plant Hopper (sudi doma) in Paddy?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Brown Plant Hopper(sudi doma) in Paddy?
KccAns: buprofzin 300ml ac
QueryText_normalized: sudi doma
Primary Answer (Level0): BPH (Brown Plant Hopper) infects rice from the tillering to booting stages, feeding on sap and causing yellowing, drying (hopper burn), and stunting. It can potentially spread the grassy stunt viral disease. To control Sudi doma/Brown Plant Hopper (BPH) in paddy fields, the integrated pest management approaches are followed. Maintain proper spacing of at least 30 cm to reduce pest spread, keep fields weed-free, avoid continuous paddy cultivation, use intermittent drainage (draining in 3-4 day intervals), and harvest all paddy plants at the same time to reduce risk and conserve and promote natural enemies such as spiders, ladybird beetles, and mirid bugs. Use light traps at night and yellow traps during the day to detect early pest buildup. If the infestation crosses the threshold level (more than 10-15 hoppers per hill), spray Dinotefuran 20 SG @ 60-80 grams per acre mixed in 200 liters of water or Triflumezopyrim 10 SC @ 90 ml per acre mixed in 200 liters of water. Rotate insecticides to prevent resistance buildup.

Rotate insecticides to prevent resistance buildup. For systemic insecticides like Dinotefuran and Triflumezopyrim used on paddy, the PHI(Pre-harvest interval) is typically 14-21 days.

This is a crucial piece of food safety information, especially since these sprays are applied during the grain formation stages.

Add Specific PHI: An expert answer must include this detail. For systemic insecticides like Dinotefuran and Triflumezopyrim used on paddy, the PHI is typically 14-21 days, and this must be stated clearly to ensure the harvested grain is safe for consumption.

QueryText: ASKING ABOUT THE CULTIVATION OF BORCCOLI IN GREEN HOUSE
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to do the cultivation of Broccoli in a greenhouse?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to do the cultivation of Broccoli in a greenhouse?
KccAns: explain in details
QueryText_normalized: asking about the cultivation of borccoli in green house
Primary Answer (Level0): Broccoli can be grown successfully in a greenhouse. Use plastic to create a well-ventilated greenhouse with a temperature range of 20–26°C during the day and 16–22°C at night. Select a suitable variety, such as Green Magic, Fiesta, or Pusa KTS-1. Create raised beds using well-drained, fertile loamy soil (pH 5.5–7) that has been enriched with 20–25 tonnes of well-decomposed FYM per acre. For 5–6 weeks, raise seedlings in trays or pots at 10–20°C. Then, transplant healthy seedlings that are 25–30 days old at 4–5 leaf stages at 45 × 45 cm apart on the raised beds, using drip irrigation to provide consistent moisture. Use mulch to suppress weeds and preserve moisture, apply a basal dose of NPK at 60:40:40 kg/acre, and top dress with 20 kg nitrogen in two splits, use compost tea or organic fertilizer every two to three weeks, and use neem-based sprays to protect plants from diseases like downy mildew and pests like aphids. Harvest compact, firm heads 2.5 to 3.5 months after transplanting by cutting with 5 to 6 inches of stalk.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Broccoli can be grown successfully in greenhouse. Use plastic to create a well-ventilated greenhouse with a temperature range of 20–26°C during the day and 16–17°C at night. Use fans and vents for proper airflow. Avoid excessive humidity that can promote fungal diseases. Select a suitable variety, such as Green Magic, Fiesta, or Pusa KTS-1. Create raised beds using well-drained, fertile, loamy soil (pH 5.5–7) that has been enriched with 10-12 tonnes of well-decomposed FYM per acre. For 5–6 weeks, raise seedlings in trays or pots at 10–20°C. Then, transplant healthy seedlings that are 25–30 days old at 4–5 leaf stages at 45 × 45 cm apart on the raised beds, and use drip irrigation to provide consistent moisture. Use mulch to suppress weeds and preserve moisture, apply a basal dose of Diammonium Phosphate (DAP) 85 kg, Muriate of Potash (MOP) 65 kg, and Urea 50 kg per acre, and Top dress with urea by applying another 45 kg in two splits (approximately 22.5 kg each) at two- to three-week intervals, use compost tea or organic fertilizer every two to three weeks, and use neem-based sprays to protect plants from diseases like downy mildew and pests like aphids. Harvest compact, firm heads 2.5 to 3.5 months after transplanting by cutting with 5 to 6 inches of stalk.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Impractical Fertilizer Dose: The biggest and only significant flaw is that the fertilizer dose is given in pure nutrients (e.g., "60 kg N, 40 kg P₂O₅, 40 kg K₂O"). This is technically correct but not practical, as a farmer cannot buy pure Nitrogen. An expert answer must translate this into quantities of actual, market-available fertilizers.

Add the Practical Translation: The advice would be perfect if it included this final step. For example, it should explain that the basal dose can be supplied by approximately 85 kg of DAP (Diammonium Phosphate), 65 kg of MOP (Muriate of Potash), and 50 kg of Urea per acre. The top dressing of 20 kg Nitrogen can then be supplied by splitting another 45 kg of Urea into two applications. This translation makes the advice immediately useful and actionable for the farmer.

QueryText: asked about castor information
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to do the cultivation of Castor?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to do the cultivation of Castor?
KccAns: given information as per the panchangam
QueryText_normalized: asked about castor information
Primary Answer (Level0): Castor a hardy oilseed crop suited to the warm and hilly zones, especially in areas with well-drained soil and moderate rainfall. For best results, you can go for certified high-yielding varieties like GCH-4, DCH-177, and TMV-5, these variety are released and approved by like (GCH-4) -  Oilseeds Research Station, Gujarat Agricultural University (GAU) and Junagadh Agricultural University (JAU), (DCH-177) -  ICAR–Directorate of Groundnut Research (DGR) and and the Indian Institute of Oilseeds Research (IIOR), (TMV-5) - State Agricultural Universities (SAUs) like Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (TNAU). These varieties are tested under All India Coordinated Research Project on Groundnut (AICRP-G) and recommended for specific zones after multi-location trials. These variety these give good yield, resist most diseases, and perform well under local conditions. For planting, keep a spacing of 90 cm between rows and 60 cm between plants — this gives good air and light, which reduces disease. You'll need about 10 to 12 kg of seed per acre, and the right time to sow is May to July, just before or with the early rains. Before sowing, if you mix 5 tonnes of well-rotted FYM or compost per acre in your land, then the soil becomes soft and holds more moisture, which helps sprouting. For fertilizer, you can give 40 kg Nitrogen, 20 kg Phosphorus, and 20 kg Potash per acre, split into two doses — half at sowing, half after 30-35 days after sowing. Early weed control is very important —so you can spray as a pre emergence Pendimethalin 30% EC @ 1 litre mixed in 200 to 250 litres of water per acre and spray within 2 days of sowing to stop weeds before they grow. Insects like semilooper and capsule borer can damage leaves and pods, these are most common pest in castor. To control it, spray Spinosad 45% (SC) 60 ml per acre or as an alternative use Indoxacarb 14.5% (SC) 80 ml per acre mixed in 200 to 400 litres of water. Use higher water volume is for taller or denser crops to ensure all plant parts are covered. If you see leaf spot or blight, as it can spoil the crop in humid weather. To control it use Mancozeb 75% WP @ 600 gram per acre, mixed in 200 litres of water. For control wilt disease, always treat your seed before sowing with Carbendazim 50% WP @ 2 gram in 1 litre of water for every 10 kg of seeds – this saves the plant right from the start. You can harvest when the pods dry and turn brown, usually around 120–140 days. Don’t wait too long or the pods may burst and you’ll lose seed. You can also intercrop with red gram or soybean — this helps earn more and keeps the soil healthy. Also, change your chemical every season to stop resistance. Don’t spray the same pesticide again and again.

Comment (Reviewer1):
1. Error: Claims varieties "are released and approved by ICAR–Directorate of Groundnut Research (DGR)"
Correction: Castor varieties are developed by ICAR-Indian Institute of Oilseeds Research (ICAR-IIOR), Hyderabad, NOT by the Directorate of Groundnut Research. Groundnut Research deals with groundnut varieties, not castor.

2. Variety Verification Issues
Partially Correct but Incomplete:

GCH-4: Correctly identified as a castor variety released in 1988
DCH-177: Correctly identified as released in 2000
TMV-5: Correctly identified as a castor variety released by TNAU in 1985

All three varieties are authentic castor varieties, but the developing institutions need correction.

3. Minor Language Issues
Grammar corrections needed:

"if you mix 5 tonnes of well-rotted FYM" (should specify "per acre")

"These variety These give good yield" (duplicate word error)

4. Missing articles in several places

6. No specific research found confirming these varieties are tested/recommended specifically for Arunachal Pradesh conditions. The varieties mentioned are primarily developed for other states (Gujarat, Tamil Nadu, Telangana). Please recheck once.

QueryText: Asking for micronutrient to be sprayed for chilly
Refined KCC Query [HF]: What micronutrients are important for spraying in Chilli?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What micronutrients are important for spraying in Chilli?
KccAns: have told him to spray tracel 1gmlit of water or amistar 1mllit of water for flower initiation
QueryText_normalized: asking for micronutrient to be sprayed for chilly
Primary Answer (Level0): Chilli crop needs proper micronutrients like zinc, boron, magnesium, and calcium to give healthy growth, good flowering, proper fruit setting, and bright colour. In Arunachal Pradesh, farmers often face problems like flower drop, pale leaves, or small fruits, which are signs of micronutrient deficiency. To solve this, farmers can spray  multi-micronutrient mixtures which is available in local agri shops. Mix 500 grams per acre in 200 litres of clean water and spray early in the morning or late in the evening when temperature is cooler. Start spraying 30 days after transplanting, and repeat it every 15 days, at least 2 to 3 times for best result. If you can see yellowing of leaves or weak plants, you can give foliar spray Zinc Sulphate (ZnSO₄ 21%) about 0.5-1.0 kg in 200 litres of water. For flower drop or poor fruit set, use Borax (Boron) at 1.5 kg per acre  for soil application and for foilar spray 300 gram of Borax in 200 litres of water.  In case you can see pale or curling leaves, spray Magnesium Sulphate at 10 kg per acre for soil application and for foliar spray 1-2 kg of Magnesium Sulphate in 200 litres of water. All these nutrients are easily available and commonly used in Arunachal Pradesh. Do not mix these sprays with strong pesticides. Always use clean water and a fine nozzle for uniform spray. These small but timely steps can improve chilli quality, increase fruit size and colour, and help farmers earn better income from their crop. Regular micronutrient management is very important for healthy chilli farming.

If you can see yellowing of leaves or weak plants, you can give foliar spray Zinc Sulphate (ZnSO₄ 21%) about 0.5-1.0 kg in 200 litres of water. For flower drop or poor fruit set, use Borax (Boron) at 1.5 kg per acre  for soil application and for foilar spray 0.1–0.2% (100–200 gram) of Borax in 200 litres of water.  In case you can see pale or curling leaves, spray Magnesium Sulphate at 10 kg per acre for soil application and for foliar spray 1-2 kg of Magnesium Sulphate in 200 litres of water. All these nutrients are easily available and commonly used in Arunachal Pradesh. Do not mix these sprays with strong pesticides. Always use clean water and a fine nozzle for uniform spray. These small but timely steps can improve chilli quality, increase fruit size and colour, and help farmers earn better income from their crop. Regular micronutrient management is very important for healthy chilli farming.

QueryText: ask about the cotronella cultivation practices and from where to procure the seedlins
Refined KCC Query [HF]: What are the recommended cultivation practices for Citronella and from where I can procure seedlings?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the recommended cultivation practices for Citronella and from where I can procure seedlings?
QueryText_normalized: ask about the cotronella cultivation practices and from where to procure the seedlins
Primary Answer (Level0): Citronella is a fragrant grass plant known for its mosquito-repelling oil. It grows well due to its humid climate and rainfall. Farmers should use high-yielding varieties like Mandakini, Manjusha, or Jor Lab C-5, which are suitable for hilly areas and give higher oil yield. Use rooted slips only (not seeds), about 12,000–14,000 slips per acre, and maintain proper spacing of 60 cm × 60 cm as it ensure proper plant growth and good air flow. The best time for planting is April to June, before the peak monsoon and select well-drained, light loamy soil with good organic content. Apply 4–5 tons FYM per acre before planting, and a basal dose of 40 kg Nitrogen, 20 kg Phosphorus and 20 kg Potash per acre. After each harvest, you can apply 40 kg Nitrogen per acre to boost regrowth. You can get quality planting materials from trusted source like ICAR Basar, KVK Papum Pare, or KVK West Siang. Keep the field weed-free for 2 months, and for chemical control, apply Glyphosate 41% SL @ 800 ml per acre in 200 – 250 litres of water before planting (on moist soil only), Do not spray on or near the citronella slips, as it is a non-selective herbicide and can damage the crop or use 2% salt solution spray after planting for soft weeds. Citronella has low pest risk, but for leaf spot disease, spray Copper oxychloride 50% WP @ 600 gram per acre mixed in 200 liters of water and as ensure sprayed evenly over the crop., and for insect safety use Neem-based pesticide (Azadirachtin 1500 ppm) @ 500 ml per acre also mixed in 200 liters of water. First harvest starts after 4 months, then every 2.5–3 months, 4–5 cuttings per year are possible. Oil should be distilled within 24 hours for better quality. Use a knapsack or power sprayer, and spray in the morning or late afternoon when temperature is cooler for best results. Always wear protective gear while spraying.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Citronella is a fragrant grass plant known for its mosquito-repelling oil. It grows well in Arunachal Pradesh due to its humid climate and rainfall. Farmers should use high-yielding varieties like Mandakini, Manjusha, or Jor Lab C-5, which are suitable for hilly areas and give higher oil yield. Use rooted slips only (not seeds), about 12,000–14,000 slips per acre, and maintain proper spacing of 60 cm × 60 cm as it ensure proper plant growth and good air flow. The best time for planting is April to June, before the peak monsoon and select well-drained, light loamy soil with good organic content. Apply 4–5 tons FYM per acre before planting, and a basal dose of 40 kg Nitrogen, 20 kg Phosphorus and 20 kg Potash per acre. After each harvest, you can apply 40 kg Nitrogen per acre to boost regrowth. You can get quality planting materials from trusted source like ICAR Basar, KVK Papum Pare, or KVK West Siang. If you are doing naturally then Keep the field weed-free for 2 months, and practice manually 2 round weeding at 20 and 40 days after planting and give light mulching with rice husk or straw to suppress weeds, which is cost effective and safe. For chemical control, apply Glyphosate 41% SL @ 800 ml per acre in 200 – 250 litres of water before planting (on moist soil only), Do not spray on or near the citronella slips, as it is a non-selective herbicide can damage crop and can suffer phytotoxicity or use 2% salt solution spray after planting for soft weeds. Citronella has low pest risk, but for leaf spot disease, spray Copper oxychloride 50% WP @ 600 gram per acre mixed in 200 liters of water and as ensure sprayed evenly over the crop., and for insect safety use Neem-based pesticide (Azadirachtin 1500 ppm) @ 500 ml per acre also mixed in 200 liters of water. First harvest starts after 4 months, then every 2.5–3 months, 4–5 cuttings per year are possible. Oil should be distilled within 24 hours for better quality. Use a knapsack or power sprayer, and spray in the morning or late afternoon when temperature is cooler for best results. Always wear protective gear while spraying.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Omit all chemical herbicides. Instead, practice two rounds of shallow mechanical weeding at 20 and 40 days after planting, followed by light mulching with rice husk or straw to suppress weeds.

Citronella is sensitive to non-selective herbicides at establishment and can suffer phytotoxicity. Mechanical weeding and organic mulch are safe, cost-effective, and approved under both organic and conventional systems in Arunachal Pradesh.

After that, you may give some chemical control

QueryText: ASKING ABOUT THE SCHEMES
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding the agriculture schemes
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding the agriculture schemes?
KccAns: details givencontact to district agriculture office
QueryText_normalized: asking about the schemes
Primary Answer (Level0): Farmers can benefit from several agriculture schemes like Atma Nirbhar Krishi Yojana (ANBY), CM Mechanization Scheme, Chief Minister's Krishi Rinn Yojana, Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana (PMFBY), which provide subsidies for seeds, fertilizers, farm machinery, training, and market linkages to improve farmers’ income and sustainability. Under the Atma Nirbhar Krishi Yojana (ANKY) scheme, the Arunachal Pradesh government provided a 45% subsidy, the bank provided a 45% loan, and the beneficiary paid the remaining 10%. The initiative offered collateral-free loans up to ₹1.6 lakh for individuals and up to ₹10 lakh for SHGs or FPOs. Crop loans with free interest up to Rs. 3 lakhs are offered by the Chief Minister's Krishi Rinn Yojana, which also offers a 4% interest subvention and an extra 3% interest relief upon prompt repayment. Tractors, power tillers, rotary tillers, and other farm equipment are all subsidized by the Chief Minister's Agriculture Mechanization Programme (CMAMP). Centrally sponsored programs like Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana (PMFBY) support farmers to insure for crop insurance, the Paramparagat Krishi Vikas Yojana (PKVY) promotes organic farming, and PM Kisan Samman Nidhi provides financial assistance to farmers.

Start the application process for these agricultural schemes to the District Agriculture Officer (DAO). The advice is excellent, but it doesn't state where to begin. An expert answer should conclude by advising the farmer that the primary government official to approach for guidance and to start the application process for these agricultural schemes is the District Agriculture Officer (DAO), and for the horticultural schemes, it is the District Horticulture Officer (DHO).

QueryText: ASKING ABOUT VARIOUS SCHEMES OF HORICULTURAL SECTOR
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding various schemes in the horticulture sector
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding various schemes in the horticulture sector?
KccAns: advised him about the schemes like-1vegetable seed production under national horticultural mission50 subsidyunder horticultural mission for north eastern and himalayan states75 subsidy2modellarge nursery2-4 haundernhb50 subsidyunder hmnes50 subsidy 3eastablishment of new orchardmax 4 ha-under nhb 50 subsidyunder hmnes 75 subsidy
QueryText_normalized: asking about various schemes of horicultural sector
Primary Answer (Level0): Farmers can benefit from horticultural schemes like Atma Nirbhar Bagwani Yojana (ANBY), MIDH, RKVY, and the CM Mechanization Scheme, which provides subsidies on high-value horticultural crops, organic farming, and machinery, along with technical and financial support. The Atma Nirbhar Bagwani Yojana scheme supports individual farmers, FPOs, or SHGs for cultivating high-value crops like dragon fruit, kiwi, orange, avocado, guava, banana, pineapple, and arecanut, as well as selected farm machinery. Under this scheme, the Arunachal Pradesh government paid a 45% subsidy, the bank gave 45% as a loan, and the beneficiary paid the remaining 10% and provided collateral-free loans up to ₹1.6 lakh for individuals and up to ₹10 lakh for SHGs or FPOs. Centrally sponsored schemes like MIDH (Mission for Integrated Development for Horticulture) support protected cultivation, mechanization, rejuvenation of old orchards, and nursery creation. Chief Minister's Krishi Rinn Yojana provides zero-interest crop loans up to Rs. 3 lakh to individual farmers and interest subvention of 4% plus an additional 3% on timely repayment. Rashtriya Krishi Vikas Yojana (RKVY) and RKVY-RAFTAAR support infrastructure development, like packaging material distribution. Under Pradhan Mantri Krishi Sinchai Yojana (PMKSY), farmers can get subsidies on drip irrigation and rainwater harvesting. The Chief Minister's mechanization schemes support the purchase of farm equipment like tractors, power tillers, water pumps, and power weeders with varied subsidies (5 lakh for tractors and 60,000 for power tillers).

QueryText: ASKING ABOUT HOW TO AVIL LOAN ON CARDAMOM CULTIVATION
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to avail loan on Cardamom cultivation?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to avail loan for Cardamom cultivation?
KccAns: explained in details
QueryText_normalized: asking about how to avil loan on cardamom cultivation
Primary Answer (Level0): Farmers can get loans for growing cardamom by applying for state government programs like Atma Nirbhar Bagwani Yojana and Chief Minister Krishi Rinn Yojana, as well as national programs like Kisan Credit Card at local banks or agriculture offices. They need to provide documents like ID and land proof to get loans without collateral and with subsidies. Atma Nirbhar Bagwani Yojana supports horticulture cultivation, including cardamom, indirectly through bank-linked credit subsidy. Under this scheme, farmers get a 45% subsidy from the Arunachal Pradesh government, the bank gives 45% as a loan, and the farmers pay the remaining 10% and provide a collateral-free loan amount up to Rs. 1.60 lakh for individuals. The Chief Minister's Krishi Rinn Yojana provides zero-interest crop loans by offering a 4% interest subvention and a 3% discount for timely repayment; it is essential to confirm the applicability for plantation crops like cardamom. Additionally, the Spices Board of India offers financial and technical assistance to expand cultivation, improve productivity and quality of planting materials, and upgrade post-harvest infrastructure with subsidies for organic farming.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Farmers can get loans for growing cardamom by applying for state government programs like Atma Nirbhar Bagwani Yojana and Chief Minister Krishi Rinn Yojana, as well as national programs like Kisan Credit Card at local banks or agriculture offices. Farmers should first contact the District Horticulture Officer (DHO), who is the primary government official responsible for providing guidance on these horticultural schemes, helping with paperwork, and ensuring proper documentation. They need to provide documents like ID and land proof to get loans without collateral and with subsidies. QueryText: ASKING ABOUT FIELD PREPARATION
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding field preparation for Mustard crop
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How should I prepare the field properly before sowing Mustard?
KccAns: explain details
QueryText_normalized: asking about field preparation
Primary Answer (Level0): Field preparation for mustard cultivation should begin soon after the harvest of the main kharif crop, typically around mid-October to early November. The selected field should have well-drained loamy or sandy loam soils with a pH between 6.0-7.5, and the land should be ploughed 2-3 times to achieve a fine tilth, followed by harrowing and proper levelling. During the final land preparation, 8-10 tons of well-decomposed farm yard manure or compost should be applied to the soil. A basal application of 54 kg Urea, 99 kg SSP, and 27 kg MOP per acre is recommended. Full phosphorus and potash and along with half of the nitrogen, should be applied at sowing, and while the remaining nitrogen should be applied 30 days after sowing as top dressing. For optimal plant growth, use 3-4 kg certified seed per acre, maintaining a row spacing of 30 cm and plant-to-plant spacing of 10-15 cm. Irrigate the field before sowing to ensure adequate soil moisture, on sloping or poorly drained soil from raised beds or ridge and furrow to improve drainage and prevent waterlogging. Better after rice harvest, use the zero tillage method if enough soil moisture is available.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Field preparation for mustard cultivation should begin soon after the harvest of the main kharif crop, typically around mid-October to early November. The selected field should have well-drained loamy or sandy loam soils with a pH between 6.0 and 7.5, and the land should be ploughed 2-3 times to achieve a fine tilth, followed by harrowing and proper leveling. During the final land preparation 8-10 tons of well-decomposed farmyard manure or compost should be applied to the soil. A basal application of 54 kg Urea, 99 kg SSP, and 27 kg MOH per acre is recommended. Full SSP and MOP, along with half of the urea should be applied at sowing while the remaining urea should be applied 30 days after sowing as top dressing. For optimal plant growth use 3-4 kg of certified seed per acre, maintaining a row spacing of 30 cm and a plant-to-plant spacing of 10-15 cm. Recommended mustard varieties for Arunachal Pradesh are TS-38, Kranti, and Pusa Bold. Irrigate the field before sowing to ensure adequate soil moisture; on sloping or poorly drained soil, use raised beds or ridge and furrow to improve drainage and prevent waterlogging, and after the rice harvest, use the zero tillage method if enough soil moisture is available.
Comment (Reviewer1):
:

Missing Variety Names: The most significant omission is that it fails to recommend any specific, high-yielding mustard varieties suitable for the region's climate. An expert answer should include names like TS-38, Kranti, or Pusa Bold.

Impractical Fertilizer Doses: The answer provides NPK doses in their pure nutrient form (kg of N, P, K). This is technically correct but not practical. The advice should be translated into quantities of actual fertilizers (e.g., X kg of Urea, Y kg of SSP, Z kg of MOP per acre) so the farmer knows exactly what to buy and apply.

Irrigate the field before sowing to ensure adequate soil moisture; on sloping or poorly drained soil, use raised beds or ridge and furrow to improve drainage and prevent waterlogging, and after the rice harvest, use the zero tillage method if enough soil moisture is available.

QueryText: SEEKING GOOD QUALITY PLANTIN MATERIAL OF LITCI
Refined KCC Query [HF]: From where can I get good-quality Litchi planting material?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: From where can I get good-quality Litchi planting material?
KccAns: advised to visit kvk and koliabor nursury
QueryText_normalized: seeking good quality plantin material of litci
Primary Answer (Level0): For high-quality litchi planting material, healthy, high-yielding, true-to-type mother trees of recommended locally adapted varieties, like Shahi, China, Rose Scented, or Bombai, should be selected from pest- and disease-free orchards managed with adequate nutrient and water supply. At the start of the monsoon, air-layering should be done on carefully selected shoots using moist rooting medium, keeping the layer attached for 60–70 days until strong fibrous roots and two to three healthy leaf flushes develop. After that, layers are carefully detached, keeping the soil ball intact, and placed in polybags, and hardened in partial shade for 4–6 weeks with gradual exposure to sunlight, then planted in deep, fertile, well-drained loamy soil with pH 5.0–7.0, avoiding heavy clay or waterlogged sites, in fields prepared by clearing vegetation, levelling the land, digging 60 × 60 × 60 cm pits one month in advance, fill them with topsoil mixed with FYM, neem cake, and single super phosphate, and establishing windbreaks like mango, eucalyptus, or arjun to protect young plants. Consult local KVK or nurseries for regionally recommended good quality litchi planting materials.

QueryText: PIT SIZE AND PLANTING DISTANCE FOR ARECANUT SAPLING
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Pit size and planting distance for Arecanut saplings
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What should be the pit size and planting distance for Arecanut saplings?
KccAns: pit size- 90 cm x 90 cm x 90 cm and planting distance between plants should be 2 metre
QueryText_normalized: pit size and planting distance for arecanut sapling
Primary Answer (Level0): For planting arecanut saplings, farmers should prepare pits of 90 cm × 90 cm × 90 cm (3 feet X 3 feet X 3 feet) in well-drained, deep soils or 60 cm × 60 cm × 60 cm in heavier or poorly drained soils. A spacing of approximately  2.7 meters × 2.7 meters(9 feet X 9 feet) between plants is recommended  to ensure adequate light, airflow, and root development. Saplings should be planted at a depth of 60 to 90 cm, although shallower depth of 45 cm in (60 cm X 60 cm X 60 cm) pits may give better yields, making it important to match planting depth and pit size to local soil and drainage conditions for healthy growth and high productivity. Planting should be done in May to June.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Planting an arecanut sapling in the dry Rabi winter season  would lead to very high mortality and crop failure, so planting should be done in May to June. For planting arecanut saplings in Arunachal Pradesh, farmers should prepare pits of 90 cm × 90 cm × 90 cm (3 feet × 3 feet × 3 feet) in well-drained, deep soils or 60 cm × 60 cm × 60 cm in heavier or poorly drained soils and fill the dug pits with a mixture of topsoil, well-decomposed Farm Yard Manure (FYM) or compost (about 10-15 kg per pit), and a small amount of insecticide to protect against termites before planting the sapling. A spacing of approximately 2.7 meters × 2.7 meters (9 feet × 9 feet) between plants is recommended to ensure adequate light, airflow, and root development. Saplings should be planted at a depth of 60 to 90 cm, although a shallower depth of 45 cm in (60 cm x 60 cm x 60 cm) pits may give better yields, making it important to match planting depth and pit size to local soil and drainage conditions for healthy growth and high productivity.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Critically Incorrect Season: The biggest flaw is that the answer fails to correct the user's query about planting in the Rabi season. It correctly states that planting should be done in May-June, but an expert must clarify that this is the start of the Kharif/Monsoon season. Planting an arecanut sapling in the dry Rabi winter season in Arunachal Pradesh would lead to very high mortality and crop failure.

Missing Pit Filling Information: To be a complete guide, the answer is missing the crucial step of how to prepare the pits. An expert must add the recommendation to fill the dug pits with a mixture of topsoil, well-decomposed Farm Yard Manure (FYM) or compost (about 10-15 kg per pit), and a small amount of insecticide to protect against termites before planting the sapling.

QueryText: which varities of litchi is most suitable for poma area

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Which Litchi varieties are best suited for the Poma area?

Primary Answer (Level0): For Poma area (Arunachal Pradesh), the best litchi varieties are Shahi, China, and Bombai. These grow well in the local climate and these variety give good-size fruits with sweet taste. Among them, Shahi is early maturing and high yielding, which is helpful for better market price. These varieties are already grown by farmers in nearby regions and are easily available from local nurseries.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0):
For the Poma region of Arunachal Pradesh, the best litchi varieties are Shahi, China, Bombai, Elachi, and Rose Scented. These varieties suit the local hill climate and are already grown by farmers in nearby regions.
- Shahi is an early maturing variety and gives high yield with sweet, good-sized fruits, helpful for fetching a better price in early markets.
- China and Bombai are also high-yielding and have good fruit quality. 
- In addition, Elachi and Rose Scented are especially suitable for hill areas of Northeast India like Arunachal Pradesh due to their adaptability and strong aroma. These varieties are available in local nurseries and perform well under Poma’s growing conditions.

QueryText: ASKING FOR a Variety of Tomatoes?
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Varieties of Tomato
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Which Tomato varieties are suitable for good cultivation?
KccAns: suggested him mhtm 301 and mhtm 401
QueryText_normalized: asking for var
Primary Answer (Level0): For tomato cultivation, farmers can choose from several quality varieties approved by ICAR and state agriculture universities. For early harvest, Pusa Early Dwarf (release from IARI) is a good choice—it gives fruits in about 60–65 days and is suitable for short-season areas. For high yield and disease resistance, Arka Rakshak and Arka Samrat which are release from IIHR, Bengaluru are excellent hybrids. Arka Rakshak is resistant to bacterial wilt, early blight, and leaf curl virus. Another good option is Pusa Rohini, also from release IARI, which is early maturing and gives uniform fruits. For late or main season planting, Punjab Chhuhara and Arka Vikas are reliable open-pollinated varieties. The best sowing time is January–February for summer crop and June–July for kharif crop. Use 100–150 grams of seed per acre, and for open pollinated varieties use 200 - 250 grams of seed per acre. Transplant 25-day-old seedlings with spacing of 60 × 45 cm for hybrids and 45 × 30 cm for desi types as proper spacing ensuring optimal plant growth, good air flow and yield. You can start harvesting usually at 60–80 days after transplanting, depending on variety. Always choose certified seeds and you collect from National Seed Corporation (NSC), State Agriculture Department or KVKs, and Reputed agri input dealers in your local area. also you apply through online IARI Seed Portal and IIHR Bengaluru online store. Always choose varieties based on your season, market demand, and disease pressure. For long-term benefits, go for resistant and high-yielding types.

Refined KCC Query [HF]: Management of Ganoderma Wilt in Coconut
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the effective management practices for Ganoderma wilt in Coconut?
KccAns: spray and apply hexaconazole 10mlliter of water or copper oxychloride 3 gramliter of water 3 times at 10 days interval in the affected plant portion near the root portion
QueryText_normalized: query regarding management of ganoderma wilt in arecanut
Primary Answer (Level0): Ganoderma wilt, also known as basal stem rot, is a serious disease affecting coconut palms. Ganoderma wilt causes yellowing and wilting of leaves, leaves may drop, and eventually the palm will die. To control this disease, integrated management practices are recommended, which combine cultural, mechanical, and chemical methods. Uproot and destroy infected palms, avoid planting cotton in previously infected areas, ensure proper drainage to avoid waterlogging, monitor palms regularly for disease symptoms, and apply biocontrol agents such as Trichoderma viride or harzianum in soil along with neem cake. Apply Hexaconazole 5 EC @10 ml in 10 litres of water or Tebuconazole 25.9 EC @10 ml in 10  litres of water per palm as a soil drench around the base of healthy coconut palms at 3-4 month intervals during disease-prone periods.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Ganoderma wilt, also known as basal stem rot, is a serious disease affecting coconut palms. Ganoderma wilt causes yellowing and wilting of leaves, leaves may drop, and eventually the palm will die. To control this disease, an integrated management practices are recommended, which combines cultural, mechanical, and chemical methods. Uproot and destroy infected palms, avoid planting coconut in previously infected areas, ensure proper drainage to avoid waterlogging, monitor palms regularly for disease symptoms, and apply biocontrol agents such as Trichoderma viride or harzianum in soil along with neem cake. For chemical control, drench the soil around the root zone of healthy palms with Hexaconazole 5 EC @ 10 ml per 10 litres of water or Tebuconazole 25.9 EC @ 10 ml per 10 litres of water, apply 15–20 litres of the prepared solution per palm at 3–4 month intervals during disease-prone periods. Maintain a Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) of at least 30 days after drenching before harvesting coconuts to ensure residue safety.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Irrelevant and Incorrect Advice: The most significant flaw is the recommendation to "avoid planting cotton in previously infected areas." This is completely irrelevant. Cotton is not a host for this fungus, nor is it a crop grown in rotation with coconut, especially in Arunachal Pradesh. This incorrect advice must be removed.

Impractical Dosage: The chemical doses for the soil drench are given as a concentration (e.g., "10 ml in 10 litres of water"). This is a good start, but an expert answer must also specify the volume of the prepared solution to be applied per palm. For a soil drench, this is typically 15-20 litres of the solution, applied to the root zone of each affected palm.

Missing Safety Information: The advice is unsafe because it completely omits the mandatory Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) or waiting period after a chemical drench before coconuts can be safely harvested. This is a critical safety rule that must be included.

Maintain a Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) of at least 30 days after drenching before harvesting coconuts to ensure residue safety.
Comment (Reviewer2):
Chemical control details are correct, but POPs recommend avoiding chemical drenches on heavily infected palms—removal is preferred.

PHI (30 days) is correct for triazoles, but must mention max 3 applications/year to prevent resistance.
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Ganoderma wilt, also known as basal stem rot , is a serious disease affecting coconut palms. QueryText: ASKING THAT HE IS NOT GETTING 16TH AND 17TH INSTALLMENT OF PM KISAN
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Why I am not receiving the 16th and 17th installments of the PM Kisan scheme?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What should I do if I am not receiving the 16th and 17th installments of the PM Kisan scheme?
KccAns: #NAME?
QueryText_normalized: asking that he is not getting 16th and 17th installment of pm kisan
Primary Answer (Level0): If you are not getting the 16th or 17th installments of PM-Kisan in Arunachal Pradesh, first check your payment status on the official PM-Kisan website (www.pmkisan.gov.in) or you can visit at the nearest Common Service Centre (CSC). Many times the problem is due to wrong Aadhaar card details, bank account errors, mismatch in land records, or incomplete eKYC. Make sure your Aadhaar is linked with your bank account and your name, father’s name, and other details match exactly in all records. If any correction is needed, visit your local agriculture department office, CSC, or Gram Panchayat office with Aadhaar card, bank passbook, land ownership papers, and mobile number. The agriculture extension officer or village-level worker will help you submit the correction request. Keep the acknowledgment slip for tracking. You can also call PM-Kisan helpline 155261 or 011-24300606 for support. Once corrections are approved, your pending installments will be credited in the next payment cycle and you will keep getting future payments on time. This scheme is a big support for farmers’ income and self-reliance, so keep your records always updated.

QueryText: ASKING ABOUT THE TERRACE GARDENING WHAT THEY CAN GROW IN THIS SEASON
Refined KCC Query [HF]: What are the best crops for terrace gardening?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the best crops for terrace gardening?
QueryText_normalized: asking about the terrace gardening what they can grow in this season
Primary Answer (Level0): Terrace gardens can be used to raise a wide range of fruits and vegetables. Select crops that thrive in warm weather during the spring (March–May). French beans, okra, lettuce, tomatoes, chiles, capsicum, bottle gourds, bitter gourds, and spinach are all recommended for spring season. In Kharif season(May to September) choose crops that require warm weather and moisture throughout the. Paddy, beans, chillies, okra, basil, coriander, pineapple, banana, orange, lemon, and guava, as well as spices like ginger and turmeric are recommended for kharif season. In Rabi season (October to February), you should choose cold-weather crops like carrots, radish, beetroot, cabbage, cauliflower, broccoli, onion, and garlic.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Terrace gardens are generally used for vegetables, fruits, herbs, and sometimes ornamental plants on the flat rooftops of houses or on stepped terraces carved into slopes. To start terrace gardening successfully, it is important to use a good potting mix made by combining equal parts of garden soil, compost or organic manure, and cocopeat or coir. Choosing the right container size is also important: use 10 to 12-inch deep pots for tomatoes and okra, medium-sized pots of 8 to 10 inches for beans and capsicum, and smaller pots of 5 to 7 inches for leafy vegetables like spinach and lettuce. Select crops that thrive in warm weather during the spring (March–May). French beans, okra, lettuce, tomatoes, chiles, capsicum, bottle gourds, bitter gourds, and spinach are all recommended for the spring season. In the Kharif season(May to September), choose crops that require warm weather and moisture throughout the period, such as beans, chillies, okra, basil, coriander, pineapple, banana, orange, lemon, and guava, as well as spices like ginger and turmeric are recommended for the Kharif season. In the Rabi season (October to February), you should choose cold-weather crops like carrots, radish, beetroot, cabbage, cauliflower, broccoli, onion, and garlic.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Ambiguous Terminology: An expert would first clarify that "Terrace Gardening" in this context likely means container gardening on a rooftop or balcony, not large-scale agricultural terraces on hillsides.

Missing Fundamental Instructions: The most significant omission is the lack of basic instructions. An expert answer must include the three most critical elements for success:

Potting Mix: A recommendation for a good potting mix recipe (e.g., a 1:1:1 ratio of Soil : Compost : Cocopeat).

Container Size: Guidance on choosing the appropriate pot size for different vegetables (e.g., 10-12 inch pots for tomatoes, 5-7 inch pots for spinach).

Specific Varieties: Naming a few specific, suitable varieties (e.g., for tomatoes, a determinate or bush-type variety like Arka Rakshak is better for pots than an indeterminate one).

QueryText: ASKING ABOUT THE CULTIVATION PRACTICES OF BEETLEWINE
Refined KCC Query [HF]: What are the recommended cultivation practices for Betelvine?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the recommended cultivation practices for Betelvine?
KccAns: explained
QueryText_normalized: asking about the cultivation practices of beetlewine
Primary Answer (Level0): Betelvine is cultivated in warm, humid, and partially shaded environments using live supports like arecanut or artificial pandals made from bamboo and shade netting. Planting is done during the monsoon season (June–July) in well-prepared raised beds, loamy or sandy loam soils rich in organic matter with drainage trenches to avoid waterlogging. Propagation should be done through stem cutting with 3-5 nodes and planted in 1.2 X 1.2 meter spacing. Frequent light irrigation is essential, especially during dry spells, and mulching with banana leaves or local materials helps conserve moisture and suppress weeds. Vines should be tied every 15-20 days along supports using banana fiber or coir rope. Fertilize the vines field with 60 kg N per acre per year, 40 kg P₂O₅ per acre per year, and 12 kg K₂O per acre per year. These are applied in split doses, with the first dose 15 days after vine lifting and subsequent doses at intervals of 40-45 days. Harvesting begins 6–8 months after planting, with mature leaves picked every 2–3 weeks, and a well-managed acre of betelvine can yield around 1.5 to 2 lakh marketable leaves per year.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Betelvine is cultivated in warm, humid, and partially shaded environments using live supports like arecanut or artificial pandals made from bamboo and shade netting. Planting is done during the monsoon season (June–July) in well-prepared raised beds, loamy or sandy loam soils rich in organic matter with drainage trenches to avoid waterlogging. Propagation should be done through stem cutting with 3-5 nodes and planted in 1.2 X 1.2 meter spacing. Frequent light irrigation is essential, especially during dry spells, and mulching with banana leaves or local materials helps conserve moisture and suppress weeds. Vines should be tied every 15-20 days along supports using banana fiber or coir rope. Fertilize the vines' field with 130 kg urea per acre per year, 100-120 kg SSP per acre per year, and 20-25 kg MOP per acre per year. These are applied in split doses, with the first dose 15 days after vine lifting and subsequent doses at intervals of 40-45 days. Harvesting begins 6–8 months after planting, with mature leaves picked every 2–3 weeks, and a well-managed acre of betelvine can yield around 1.5 to 2 lakh marketable leaves per year.
Comment (Reviewer1): Translate Nutrients into Fertilizers: The answer provides the fertilizer dose in terms of pure nutrients (e.g., 60 kg N, 40 kg P₂O₅ per acre). While technically correct, the advice would be even more farmer-friendly if it translated these nutrient doses into quantities of actual, market-available fertilizers. For example, it could add that "60 kg of Nitrogen can be supplied by approximately 130 kg of Urea," and provide similar conversions for Phosphorus (using SSP or DAP) and Potassium (using MOP). This is the only small addition needed to make it a perfect, actionable guide.
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): Betelvine is cultivated in warm, humid, and partially shaded environments using live supports like arecanut or artificial pandals made from bamboo and shade netting. Planting is done during the optimal season of November-December or January-February in well-prepared raised beds, loamy or sandy loam soils rich in organic matter with drainage trenches to avoid waterlogging. Propagation should be done through stem cutting with 3-5 nodes and planted in 1.2 X 1.2 meter spacing. Frequent light irrigation is essential, especially during dry spells, and mulching with banana leaves or local materials helps conserve moisture and suppress weeds. Vines should be tied every 15-20 days along supports using banana fiber or coir rope. Fertilize the vines' field with 130 kg urea per acre per year, 100-120 kg SSP per acre per year, and 20-25 kg MOP per acre per year. These are applied in split doses, with the first dose 15 days after vine lifting and subsequent doses at intervals of 40-45 days. Harvesting begins 6–8 months after planting, with mature leaves picked every 2–3 weeks, and a well-managed acre of betelvine can yield around 1.5 to 2 lakh marketable leaves per year.
Comment (Reviewer2):
Spacing of 1.2 x 1.2 m seems wide; POPs usually recommend closer spacing ~60-90 cm between plants depending on system.

Urea 130 kg/acre/year is high; POPs recommend balanced fertilization based on soil test, usually ~100 kg N/acre/year split.
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Betel vine cultivation requires careful attention to the region's unique hilly terrain and climatic conditions. Choose locations with a tropical humid climate with temperatures between 10°C to 30°C, which are ideal for betel vine growth. Select sites with high relative humidity and partially shaded environments using live supports like arecanut or artificial pandals made from bamboo and shade netting. Planting is done during the optimal season of November-December or January-February in well-prepared raised beds, loamy or sandy loam soils rich in organic matter, with drainage trenches to avoid waterlogging. Well-drained upland areas with slight slopes are preferred over waterlogged lowlands. Prepare raised beds of 2 meters in width with drainage trenches (0.5m wide × 0.5m deep) between beds. Construct protective structures called "Pan Boroj" using bamboo poles and thatched roofing with paddy straw or dry grass for shade. Plant live supports like Agathi (Sesbania grandiflora) in rows to support vine climbing. Propagation should be done through healthy stem cuttings with 3-4 nodes, and 45 cm plant-to-plant spacing is maintained in two rows per bed. Weekly irrigation is essential, especially during dry spells, and mulching with banana leaves or local materials helps conserve moisture and suppress weeds. Vines should be tied every 15-20 days along supports using banana fiber or coir rope. Apply fertilizer based on soil test recommendation, a general guideline include: 60 kg nitrogen per acre (30 kg through neem cake and 30 kg through urea), 40 kg Phosphorus (P₂O₅) through single superphosphate(SSP), and 12 kg Potassium(K₂O) through muriate of potash(MOP) in three split doses—first at 15 days after lifting the vines and the second and third at 40–45 days intervals; also apply about 0.8 tonnes neem leaves or Calotropis leaves per acre in two split doses (0.4 tonnes each), covering them with mud on the beds. In the hilly terrain of Arunachal Pradesh, select naturally sheltered locations or create windbreaks to protect from strong mountain winds. Harvesting begins 6–8 months after planting, with mature leaves picked every 2–3 weeks, and a well-managed acre of betelvine can yield around 1.5 to 2 lakh marketable leaves per year.

QueryText: for finger millet is dibbing better or transplanting
Refined KCC Query [HF]: For Finger millet, which method is better: dibbling or transplanting?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: For Finger millet, which method is better: dibbling or transplanting?
KccAns: it is better to tranplant the finger miilets
QueryText_normalized: for finger millet is dibbing better or transplanting
Primary Answer (Level0): Dibbling is better than transplanting for finger millet. Dibbling saves labour, needs less water, conserve moisture for long time, is easier for hilly and rainfed areas and cost-effective. Growing plants by direct dibbling after first good rain gives better crop stand and root development. Transplanting is more labour- intensive and needs a nursery, which is not practical for many farmers in the region. Use improved varieties like VL Mandua 352 or GPU 67, which are suited to Arunachal’s conditions. They are known for their high yield potential and suitability for rainfed conditions. These varieties are promoted by agricultural research institutes for the Northeast. The recommended seed rate of 8-10 kg per acre and spacing of 25 x 10 cm are correct for this method. After sowing, to control weeds, apply Pendimethalin 30% EC at 1 litres per acre as pre-emergence within 3 days of sowing. Mix it in 200 litres water and spray evenly to ensure full coverage. If second flush of weeds appears, do one hand weeding at 20-25 days after sowing.  Before sowing, apply 2 quintals compost and 5 kg Trichoderma per acre to improve soil health and managing soil-borne diseases. This is a highly recommended and sustainable approach. Keep field clean for the first 40 days. This simple method gives strong root growth, better tillering, and good yield under local conditions.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): In Arunachal Pradesh, dibbling is better than transplanting for finger millet. Dibbling saves labour, needs less water, conserves moisture for a long time, is easier for hilly and rainfed areas, and is cost-effective. Growing plants by direct dibbling after the first good rain gives better crop stand and root development. Transplanting is more labour-intensive and needs a nursery, which is not practical for many farmers in the region. Use improved, region-tested varieties like VM 4 (VL Mandua 4) or Narendra Mandua 4, which are promoted by ICAR-RCNEH, Basar and the Arunachal Pradesh Krishi Vigyan Kendras for local rainfed conditions. They are known for good yield potential and adaptability to the Northeast’s climate. The recommended seed rate of 6-7 kg per acre and spacing of 25 × 10 cm are correct for this method. After sowing, to control weeds, apply Pendimethalin 30% EC @ 1 litre per acre as pre-emergence within 3 days of sowing. Mix in 200 - 250 litres of water and spray evenly for full coverage. If a second flush of weeds appears, do one hand weeding at 20–25 days after sowing. Before sowing, apply 2 quintals of compost and 5 kg Trichoderma per acre to improve soil health and manage soil-borne diseases. This is a highly recommended and sustainable approach. Keep the field clean for the first 40 days. This simple method gives strong root growth, better tillering, and good yield under Arunachal’s local conditions.

Variety recommendations: VL Mandua-352 and GPU-67 are developed for peninsular India and have not been officially released for Arunachal Pradesh.
Instead, recommend region-tested, rainfed finger millet varieties such as VM 4 (VL Mandua 4) or Narendra Mandua 4, which are promoted by ICAR-RCNEH, Basar, and the Arunachal Pradesh Krishi Vigyan Kendras.

QueryText: QUERY ABOUT KISSAN CREDIT CARD
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Query about Kisan Credit Card (KCC)
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the Kisan Credit Card (KCC) scheme?
KccAns: advised to contact agri off of any nationalised bank for details
QueryText_normalized: query about kissan credit card
Primary Answer (Level0): Farmers can access short-term crop loans and credit for allied agricultural activities through the central government's Kisan Credit Card (KCC) scheme, which provides loans up to ₹3 lakh at a interest rate of 7% per annum and loans up to ₹1.6 lakh under the KCC scheme are collateral-free, meaning the farmer does not need to mortgage their land or provide any other security to the bank.  Additionally, the Government of Arunachal Pradesh has launched the Chief Minister’s Krishi Rinn Yojana, a state-level initiative providing an additional interest subvention of 4% reducing the effective interest rate to just 3% for eligible farmers. Moreover, if the farmer repays the loan within one year, an extra 3% rebate is given. If you want to apply Kisan Credit card, visit your nearest bank with land documents and ID proof.

Moreover, if the farmer repays the loan within one year, an extra 3% rebate is given. If you want to apply Kisan Credit card, visit your nearest bank with land documents and ID proof.

Missing the Collateral-Free Limit: The most significant and helpful piece of information for a small or marginal farmer is missing. The answer provides the total loan limit of ₹3 lakh, but an expert answer must also highlight the special provision for smaller loans.

This is a primary feature of the scheme designed to ensure easy credit access for all farmers, and it is the most important detail to add to make this answer complete.

QueryText: ask about the govt schemes for jathropa in arunachal pradesh and from where to procure further information
Refined KCC Query [HF]: What government schemes are available for Jatropha cultivation in Arunachal Pradesh and from where can I get more information?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What government schemes are available for Jatropha cultivation in Arunachal Pradesh, and from where can I get more information?
KccAns: this schemes can be obtained from nabard and director of horticulture and agriculture
QueryText_normalized: ask about the govt schemes for jathropa in arunachal pradesh and from where to procure further information
Primary Answer (Level0): In Arunachal Pradesh, farmers can grow Jatropha under the scheme like Atma Nirbhar Bagwani Yojana Atma Nirbhar Krishi Yojana (ANKY), Mission for Integrated Development of Horticulture (MIDH), run by the Horticulture Department, these schemes generally offer a mix of bank loans (around 45%), government subsidies (around 45%), and a small beneficiary contribution (around 10%). This scheme provides 40% subsidy for Scheduled Castes (SC), Scheduled Tribes (ST), women, and 50% subsidy for general category farmers on planting material, drip irrigation, shade net, polyhouse, and small tools. It is a credit-linked scheme, so farmers can also get bank loan with 3–5% interest subsidy, which reduces their loan burden. The scheme supports individual farmers, SHGs, and FPOs. You can apply through your District Horticulture Office or online via the Chief Minister’s Dashboard Portal. To apply, submit land ownership documents or lease certificate, Aadhaar card, bank passbook, passport-size photo, and SHG/FPO registration papers if applicable. For full benefit, contact your local Horticulture Officer for the latest subsidy rate, interest details, and to verify documents required. Jatropha grows well on wasteland or unused land, and its seeds are used for bio-diesel production, which has good market demand. This crop helps farmers earn extra income, use fallow land, become self-reliant, and avoid high-interest loans from moneylenders.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): In Arunachal Pradesh, farmers can grow Jatropha under support from schemes like Atma Nirbhar Bagwani Yojana (ANBY), Atma Nirbhar Krishi Yojana (ANKY), and MIDH (Mission for Integrated Development of Horticulture), which are run by the Horticulture Department. These schemes are separate — ANBY is focused on horticulture, offering 45% government subsidy, 45% bank loan, and 10% farmer contribution for components like planting materials, polyhouse, shade net, drip irrigation, and farm tools, while ANKY covers broader agri-development with a different financial structure. Under these schemes, SC/ST/women and Nothest hilly regions farmers generally receive higher subsidies (up to 50–60%), while general category farmers receive 40–45%, depending on the specific scheme and component. These are credit-linked schemes, where eligible farmers can also get bank loans with interest subvention of 3%, which reduces their loan burden. To apply, visit your local District Horticulture Office directly. Prepare your land ownership or lease certificate, Aadhaar card, bank passbook, passport-size photo, and SHG/FPO registration papers (if applicable). Jatropha is suitable for wastelands and fallow lands, and its seeds are used for bio-diesel, which has growing market value. This crop helps farmers utilize unused land, increase income, and become more self-reliant without depending on moneylenders. For full benefit and accurate latest subsidy rates, contact your local horticulture officer or Krishi Vigyan Kendra (KVK).
Comment (Reviewer1):
- "Atma Nirbhar Bagwani Yojana" and "Atma Nirbhar Krishi Yojana" are treated as the same scheme with mixed subsidy percentages.
These are separate schemes with different objectives. ANBY focuses on horticulture with specific financial structure, while ANKY has different coverage and benefits.
Several sources shows these are distinct schemes with different implementation structures. ANBY has a 45% government contribution + 45% bank loan + 10% farmer contribution model. Mixing them provides incorrect financial guidance to farmers

- Claims "50% subsidy for general category farmers" which appears to reverse the typical subsidy pattern.
Generally, SC/ST/women farmers receive higher subsidies (50-60%) while general category receives standard rates (40-45%).

- States farmers can apply through "Chief Minister's Dashboard Portal" for scheme benefits.
The CM Dashboard is primarily a monitoring tool, not an application portal. Direct farmers to District Horticulture Office or designated application centers.

Multiple sources confirm CM Dashboard is for governance monitoring and transparency, not farmer applications. Providing correct application channels saves farmers time and ensures proper submission

These schemes are separate — ANBY is focused on horticulture, offering 45% government subsidy, 45% bank loan, and 10% farmer contribution for components like planting materials, polyhouse, shade net, drip irrigation, and farm tools, while ANKY covers broader agri-development with a different financial structure. Under these schemes, SC/ST/women and Nothest hilly regions farmers generally receive higher subsidies (up to 50–60%), while general category farmers receive 40–45%, depending on the specific scheme and component. These are credit-linked schemes, where eligible farmers can also get bank loans with interest subvention of 3%, which reduces their loan burden. To apply, visit your local District Horticulture Office directly. Prepare your land ownership or lease certificate, Aadhaar card, bank passbook, passport-size photo, and SHG/FPO registration papers (if applicable). Jatropha is suitable for wastelands and fallow lands, and its seeds are used for bio-diesel, which has growing market value. This crop helps farmers utilize unused land, increase income, and become more self-reliant without depending on moneylenders. For full benefit and accurate latest subsidy rates, contact your local horticulture officer or Krishi Vigyan Kendra (KVK).
Comment (Reviewer2):
"Jathropa" spelling → correct is "Jatropha".

ANBY and ANKY financial structure: clarify that ANBY is 45:45:10 credit-linked back-ended subsidy, not upfront grant.

“Higher subsidies (up to 50–60%)” → needs to specify NE & hilly area advantage.
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): In Arunachal Pradesh, farmers can grow Jatropha under support from schemes like Atma Nirbhar Bagwani Yojana (ANBY), Atma Nirbhar Krishi Yojana (ANKY), and MIDH (Mission for Integrated Development of Horticulture), which are run by the Horticulture Department. These schemes are separate — ANBY is focused on horticulture, offering 45% government subsidy, 45% bank loan, and 10% farmer contribution for components like planting materials, polyhouse, shade net, drip irrigation, and farm tools, while ANKY covers broader agri-development with a different financial structure. Under these schemes, SC/ST/women and Nothest hilly regions farmers generally receive higher subsidies (up to 50–60%), while general category farmers receive 40–45%, depending on the specific scheme and component. These are credit-linked schemes, where eligible farmers can also get bank loans with interest subvention of 3%, which reduces their loan burden. To apply, visit your local District Horticulture Office directly. Prepare your land ownership or lease certificate, Aadhaar card, bank passbook, passport-size photo, and SHG/FPO registration papers (if applicable). Jatropha is suitable for wastelands and fallow lands, and its seeds are used for bio-diesel, which has growing market value. This crop helps farmers utilize unused land, increase income, and become more self-reliant without depending on moneylenders. For full benefit and accurate latest subsidy rates, contact your local horticulture officer or Krishi Vigyan Kendra (KVK).

QueryText: Cultural practices for colocasia
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Cultural practices for Colocasia
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the recommended cultural practices of Colocasia?
KccAns: spacing- 45 cmpit size-30-50 cmdepth-25 to 7 cmfertiliser- urea 2kgssp 4 kg and mop 6 kg fym 2-3 tonnes
QueryText_normalized: cultural practices for colocasia
Primary Answer (Level0): Farmers grow colocasia(taro/arbi) mostly as a mixed crop in jhum (shifting cultivation) fields alongside paddy, maize, ginger, chilli, turmeric, cucurbits, or in homestead gardens. If you want to grow colcasia, select well-drained loamy or sandy-loam soil, plough and dig the land 2-3 times to make fine tilth, plant healthy corms or cormels at the start of the rainy season (April–May) with a spacing of 45 cm × 30 cm, use 200–250 kg of healthy corms or cormels as seed material, incorporate farmyard manure (5-6 tons per acre) before planting, do 2-3 hand weeding to remove weeds, light earthing-up should be done when plants are 30–40 days old to cover developing corms, ensure proper drainage to avoid waterlogging in valley areas, maintain adequate soil moisture in hill slopes by mulching, and harvest 5–7 months after planting when leaves start yellowing and drying.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Farmers grow colocasia(taro/arbi) mostly as a mixed crop in jhum (shifting cultivation) fields alongside paddy, maize, ginger, chilli, turmeric, cucurbits, or in homestead gardens. If you want to grow colcasia, select well-drained loamy or sandy-loam soil, plough and dig the land 2-3 times to make fine tilth, plant healthy corms or cormels at the start of the rainy season (April–May) with a spacing of 45 cm × 30 cm, use 200–250 kg of healthy corms or cormels as seed material, incorporate farmyard manure (5-6 tons per acre) before planting, do 2-3 hand weeding to remove weeds, light earthing-up should be done when plants are 30–40 days old to cover developing corms, ensure proper drainage to avoid waterlogging in valley areas, maintain adequate soil moisture in hill slopes by mulching, and harvest 5–7 months after planting when leaves start yellowing and drying.
Comment (Reviewer1): Missing Yield Quantification: The most critical piece of information for a farmer is missing. The answer provides all the steps but fails to mention the expected outcome. An expert answer must include the yield potential in quintals or tonnes per acre. A well-managed colocasia crop in this region can yield approximately 60-80 quintals of corms per acre, and adding this number would make the guide complete.
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): Colocasia (taro/arbi) is predominantly grown as a mixed crop in jhum (shifting cultivation) fields alongside paddy, maize, ginger, chilli, turmeric, cucurbits, or in homestead gardens. This traditional practice helps maintain soil fertility and supports diverse cropping systems. If you want to grow Colcasia, select well-drained loamy or sandy-loam soil with good organic matter. Prepare the land by ploughing and digging 2-3 times to achieve a fine tilth. Plant healthy corms or cormels at the onset of the rainy season (April–May) with a spacing of 45 cm × 30 cm, using about 200–250 kg of seed material per acre. Incorporate 5-6 tons of well-decomposed farmyard manure before planting to enrich the soil. Conduct 2-3 rounds of hand weeding to control weeds and perform light earthing-up when plants are 30–40 days old to cover and support developing corms. Since the crop prefers moist conditions but is sensitive to waterlogging, ensure proper drainage, especially in valley areas. On hill slopes, maintain adequate soil moisture using mulching with banana leaves or local organic materials to conserve moisture and suppress weeds. Harvesting typically occurs  7–9 months after planting when the leaves begin to yellow and dry. Under good management, colocasia can yield approximately 60-80 quintals of corms per acre.  Leaves and petioles are also harvested periodically for use as vegetables or fodder. Additionally, avoid deep cultivation to prevent corm damage, and perform light hoeing and earthing-up twice (at 30–45 days and again at 60–75 days). The leafy parts may be smothered about one month before harvest to enhance corm development. Irrigate adequately, particularly during dry spells, using light and frequent watering; stop irrigation 3-4 weeks before harvest.
