QueryText: my pig has lots of tiks n lice in its body what to do
Refined KCC Query [HF]: My pig has lots of ticks and lice on its body. What to do?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to treat ticks and lice in Pigs?
KccAns: take butox deltametrinadd 2ml per litre of water dernch the pig in it or bath the pig by using cloth use the residue water to spray on the near by area of the shed avoid any intake of the medicine keep it away from reach of children
QueryText_normalized: my pig has lots of tiks n lice in its body what to do
Primary Answer (Level0): The first and most important step is to isolate the infested pig from the rest of your herd immediately. This is crucial to prevent the parasites from spreading to your other animals. Ticks and lice can easily transfer through direct contact or via a contaminated environment. You must thoroughly clean and disinfect the pig's original living area after moving it. Next,you should consult a veterinarian for a precise diagnosis and treatment plan. A veternary can confirm the type of parasites and prescribe the most effective and safe treatment product. They can also rule out any secondary health issues caused by the infestation,such as anemia or skin infections. Treatment typically involves the application of a parasiticide,which is a medication that kills parasites. These medicines come in several forms,including pour-on solutions, injectables, and sprays. It is absolutely vital that you use a product specifically labeled for use in pigs. The dosage must be calculated based on the pig's body weight to be both effective and safe. You must carefully read and follow all the instructions on the product label. Pay close attention to the withdrawal period,which is the required time between treatment and when the pig can be slaughtered for meat. Treat all pigs that have been in contact with the infested animal,even if they show no signs yet. This ensures you eliminate the entire population of parasites and prevent immediate re-infestation. Alongside treating the pig,you must also treat its environment. Ticks can hide in cracks,woodpiles, and bedding, while lice eggs can be attached to pen walls and feeders. Remove all old bedding and dispose of it properly. Thoroughly scrub and spray the pen,walls, and equipment with a recommended insecticide. Repeat the environmental cleaning as advised on the insecticide label to kill any newly hatched parasites. Provide supportive care to the infested pig to help it recover. Ensure it has a clean,dry, and comfortable place to rest. Offer a highly nutritious diet with adequate iron and protein to help it recover from any blood loss. Preventing future infestations is just as important as treating the current one. Conduct regular health checks on your pigs,looking closely through their hair for signs of parasites. Maintain clean,dry, and uncrowded living conditions for your animals. Consider using approved preventive parasite control measures as part of your routine herd management. A veterinarian is your best resource for creating an effective long-term parasite management strategy for your farm.

These medicines come in several forms, including pour-on solutions, injectables, and sprays. It is absolutely vital that you use a product specifically labelled for use in pigs. The dosage must be calculated based on the pig's body weight to be both effective and safe. You must carefully read and follow all the instructions on the product label. Pay close attention to the withdrawal period, which is the required time between treatment and when the pig can be slaughtered for meat. Treat all pigs that have been in contact with the infested animal, even if they show no signs yet. This ensures you eliminate the entire population of parasites and prevent immediate re-infestation. Alongside treating the pig, you must also treat its environment. Ticks can hide in cracks, woodpiles, and bedding, while lice eggs can be attached to pen walls and feeders. Remove all old bedding and dispose of it properly. Thoroughly scrub and spray the pen, walls, and equipment with a recommended insecticide. Repeat the environmental cleaning as advised on the insecticide label to kill any newly hatched parasites. Provide supportive care to the infested pig to help it recover. Ensure it has a clean, dry, and comfortable place to rest. Offer a highly nutritious diet with adequate iron and protein to help it recover from any blood loss. Preventing future infestations is just as important as treating the current one. Conduct regular health checks on your pigs, looking closely through their hair for signs of parasites. Maintain clean, dry, and uncrowded living conditions for your animals. Consider using approved preventive parasite control measures as part of your routine herd management. A veterinarian is your best resource for creating an effective long-term parasite management strategy for your farm.

QueryText: ask about the control measures for the foot and mouth disease
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Control measures for the Foot and Mouth disease
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control the Foot and Mouth disease in Livestock?
KccAns: fmd vaccines are supplied by the veterinary deptfor free of cost
QueryText_normalized: ask about the control measures for the foot and mouth disease
Primary Answer (Level0): The single most important action is the immediate and total isolation of any suspected animal. This means separating the sick animal from all healthy livestock in a secure enclosure. A strict quarantine must be imposed on the entire farm or premises. This involves prohibiting the movement of all animals,people, and vehicles onto or off of the property. The immediate notification of the local government veterinarian is a legal requirement in most regions. This official reporting triggers a rapid response from animal health authorities. Trained officials will visit to confirm the diagnosis through clinical examination and laboratory testing. Once confirmed,a control zone is typically established around the infected farm. Movement restrictions are enforced within this zone to prevent any possible spread. A common control measure is the humane culling of infected animals and those that have been exposed. This stamping-out policy is used to eliminate the source of the virus and stop its transmission. The carcasses must be disposed of safely through burning,build, or rendering under veterinary supervision. Thorough cleaning and disinfection of all contaminated premises is absolutely essential. This includes buildings,vehicles, equipment, and any other exposed materials. Specific disinfectants proven to kill the FMD virus,like citric acid or commercial virucidal agents, must be used. Vaccination can be used as a control tool in certain situations,known as ring vaccination. This involves vaccinating all susceptible animals in a ring around the infected outbreak area. Vaccination does not cure sick animals but can protect healthy ones and slow the virus's spread. It is crucial to practice rigorous personal biosecurity. Anyone handling animals must disinfect their boots,clothing, and hands before and after contact. Equipment should not be shared between isolated infected animals and the healthy herd. A detailed record of all movements and actions taken must be maintained for tracing purposes. These control measures are disruptive but are necessary to contain the outbreak. The goal is to eradicate the virus,protect the national livestock industry, and resume trade. All actions should be carried out under the direct guidance and supervision of the veterinary authorities.

QueryText: my piglet is two weeks can i go for castration
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Can I castrate my 2 weeks old piglet?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Can I castrate my 2 weeks old piglet?
KccAns: it is bit young can wait for a month let the piglet grow
QueryText_normalized: my piglet is two weeks can i go for castration
Primary Answer (Level0): Castrating a piglet at two weeks of age is generally acceptable and falls within the commonly recommended timeframe. The standard recommended period for castration is between 3 and 14 days of age. Therefore,your two-week-old (14-day-old) piglet is at the very upper end of the ideal window. It is crucial to ensure the piglet is strong,healthy, and has been nursing well before any procedure is considered. A piglet that is weak,small for its age, or shows any signs of illness should not be castrated. The procedure becomes more stressful and slightly more difficult as the piglet gets older and larger. At two weeks,the testicles are still relatively small, which can make the surgery technically straightforward. However,the piglet will be more mobile and may require more secure restraint than a younger piglet. Pain management is a critical factor for animal welfare at this age. The use of a local anesthetic is highly recommended to numb the area and minimize pain during the procedure. Providing a long-acting pain relief medication after the surgery is also considered a best practice. The procedure must be performed with strict hygiene using sterilized instruments. A sharp,clean scalpel blade should be used to make precise incisions and minimize tissue damage. Aftercare is very important to prevent complications like infection or scirhous cord. The piglet should be placed in a clean,dry, and comfortable pen to recover. Monitor it closely for signs of excessive bleeding,swelling, or infection in the following days. The ultimate decision should be made in consultation with a veterinarian if possible. A veternary can best assess the piglet's health and perform the procedure with the highest standard of care. If you are not experienced in piglet castration,seeking professional help is strongly advised to ensure the piglet's welfare.

QueryText: maggot infestation in goat what can i do
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Maggot infection in Goat
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Maggot infection in Goat?
KccAns: clip the hair around the woundplug terpine oil let the maggot die and remove the maggotsand put himax oinment
QueryText_normalized: maggot infestation in goat what can i do
Primary Answer (Level0): In Arunachal Pradesh, maggot infestation also known as myiasis or fly strike is a serious  painful condition. The first step is to isolate the infected goat from the rest of the herd immediately. This allows you to treat the animal without stressing it further and prevents the spread of flies to others. You must carefully assess the extent of the infestation by examining the affected area,which is often the rear end, wounds, or soiled skin. The next crucial step is to carefully remove all the maggots from the goat's skin and tissue. This process requires great care to avoid causing more pain or damage. You will need to clip or shave the hair from around the infested area to see clearly and allow for proper cleaning. The maggots must be physically removed using tweezers or forceps. After physical removal,the area must be thoroughly cleaned and disinfected. A common and effective solution for flushing out deep maggots is hydrogen peroxide. It helps to kill remaining maggots and clean the wound through its bubbling action. After rinsing with peroxide,the wound should be cleaned again with a mild antiseptic solution like diluted betadine or chlorhexidine. It is absolutely essential to consult a veterinarian as soon as possible. A veterinariant can prescribe appropriate medications that are critical for recovery. They will likely prescribe a topical insecticide spray or ointment specifically designed to kill maggots. The veterinarian will also prescribe a course of antibiotics to combat the severe bacterial infection that always accompanies maggot wounds. Injectable pain relief and anti-inflammatory medication are also very important for the goat's welfare. The underlying cause of the infestation must be identified and addressed. Myiasis is often caused by soiling of the rear end from diarrhea,or by wounds from shearing, fighting, or other injuries. Preventing future infestations is just as important as treating the current one. Maintaining good hygiene in the goat's living quarters is the best prevention. This includes regularly cleaning pens and removing damp,soiled bedding. Implementing a regular worm control program is vital to prevent diarrhea that soils the tail and rear legs. You should regularly check your goats,especially during warm weather, for any signs of wounds or soiling. Treating any wound immediately with an antiseptic spray can deter flies from laying eggs.  Providing a clean,dry, and well-ventilated environment is the most effective long-term strategy for preventing fly strike.

QueryText: maggot in cow
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Maggot in Cow
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Maggot infection in cow?
KccAns: wash the wound with saline water apply turpentine oil plug it for some time and remove the dead worms apply himax or charmil oinment
QueryText_normalized: maggot in cow
Primary Answer (Level0): In Arunachal Pradesh, for controlling maggot in cow the first and most important step is to immediately isolate the affected animal from the herd. This prevents the spread of flies and allows you to treat the cow without causing stress to the others. You must carefully examine the cow to locate all infested areas,which are often soiled wounds, the navel of newborns, or the rear end. The next crucial step is the physical removal of all maggots from the wound. This process requires care to avoid causing further pain or damage to the tissue. You will need to clip or shave the hair around the infested area to get a clear view and allow for proper cleaning. The maggots must be carefully extracted using tweezers or forceps. After physical removal,the wound must be thoroughly cleaned and disinfected. A common and effective solution for flushing out deep maggots is hydrogen peroxide. The bubbling action helps kill remaining maggots and clean deep pockets within the wound. After rinsing with peroxide,the area should be cleaned again with a mild antiseptic solution like diluted povidone-iodine or chlorhexidine. It is absolutely essential to consult a veterinarian as soon as possible. A veterinarian can prescribe appropriate medications that are critical for recovery. They will likely prescribe a topical insecticide powder or spray specifically designed to kill maggots. The veterinarian will also prescribe a course of antibiotics to combat the severe bacterial infection that accompanies the infestation. Injectable pain relief and anti-inflammatory medication are also very important for the cow's welfare. The underlying cause of the infestation must be identified and addressed. Preventing future infestations is just as important as treating the current one. Maintaining good hygiene in the cattle's environment is the best prevention. This includes regularly cleaning pens and removing damp,soiled bedding. Implementing a strict wound management protocol is vital. Any cut or injury should be immediately cleaned and treated with a fly-repellent antiseptic spray. Pour-on insecticides or fly repellent tags can be used as a preventive measure during high-risk seasons. Providing a clean,dry, and well-ventilated environment is the most effective long-term strategy for preventing fly strike.

QueryText: what vaccines should be given to the mithuns
Refined KCC Query [HF]: What vaccines should be given to the Mithuns?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What vaccination should be given to the Mithuns?
KccAns: the mithuns may be vaccinated with foot and mouth diseases hsbq vaccines both itramuscular and by sub cuteneousapproach the nearest veterinary dispensary for free vaccines
QueryText_normalized: what vaccines should be given to the mithuns
Primary Answer (Level0): In Arunachal Pradesh, vaccination is a vital practice for protecting the health and productivity of Mithun. A core set of vaccines is considered essential for all animals due to common and dangerous diseases. The first and most crucial vaccine is for Foot and Mouth Disease. This vaccine requires a first dose at three months of age. A booster dose is given four weeks after the initial vaccination. Because immunity is short-lived,revaccination must occur every six months for life. Another essential vaccine protects against Haemorrhagic Septicaemia. This disease is often fatal and outbreaks are common during monsoon seasons. The first dose of this vaccine is given at six months of age. An annual booster is required,ideally administered before the rainy season begins. Protection against Black Quarter,a fatal bacterial infection, is also a core requirement. This vaccine is first administered when the animal is six months old. An annual revaccination is necessary to maintain immunity. Optional vaccines are used based on the specific disease risks in a local area. In regions where anthrax is a known threat,an annual vaccination is recommended. For female calves,a one-time vaccination against brucellosis is available. This is given between four to eight months of age to prevent abortions. It is critical to only vaccinate animals that are healthy and not under stress. All vaccines must be sourced reliably and kept cold until the moment of use. Using sterile equipment and proper restraint ensures a safe procedure. Maintaining detailed records of each vaccination is essential for effective management. Consulting a local veterinarian is the best way to create a tailored health plan.

Because immunity is short-lived, revaccination must occur every six months for life. Another essential vaccine protects against hemorrhagic septicemia. This disease is often fatal, and outbreaks are common during monsoon seasons. The first dose of this vaccine is given at six months of age. An annual booster is required, ideally administered before the rainy season begins. Protection against Black Quarter, a fatal bacterial infection, is also a core requirement. This vaccine is first administered when the animal is six months old. An annual revaccination is necessary to maintain immunity. Optional vaccines are used based on the specific disease risks in a local area. In regions where anthrax is a known threat, an annual vaccination is recommended. For female calves, a one-time vaccination against brucellosis is available. This is given between four and eight months of age to prevent abortions. It is critical to only vaccinate animals that are healthy and not under stress. All vaccines must be sourced reliably and kept cold until the moment of use. Using sterile equipment and proper restraint ensures a safe procedure. Maintaining detailed records of each vaccination is essential for effective management. Consulting a local veterinarian is the best way to create a tailored health plan.

It is critical to only vaccinate animals that are healthy and not under stress. All vaccines must be sourced reliably and kept cold until the moment of use. Using sterile equipment and proper restraint ensures a safe procedure. Maintaining detailed records of each vaccination is essential for effective management. Consulting a local veterinarian is the best way to create a tailored health plan.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the vaccination schedule in Mithun?
KccAns: the vaccination in mithun should be given twice in a year before monsoon and after winter in gap of six months vaccines of footand mouth diseases and hsbq should be given

QueryText: how to deal with the ticks and lice infestation
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to deal with the ticks and lice infestation?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control the ticks and lice infection?
KccAns: wash or bath the animal with butox with 25 mal per litre water 0r apply poron from neck to the tail region from back
QueryText_normalized: how to deal with the ticks and lice infestation
Primary Answer (Level0): The first step is to correctly identify the problem and understand that control is a two-part process: treating the animal and treating its environment, like Ticks are larger, often visible attached to the skin, and can be felt as bumps when running your hand over the animal.Lice are smaller and harder to see; their presence is often indicated by intense itching, restlessness, and a rough, matted coat.The most important action is to isolate the severely infested animal from the rest of the herd to prevent the parasites from spreading.You must then choose an appropriate parasiticide, which is a chemical specifically designed to kill these parasites.These products come in several forms, including pour-on solutions, sprays, injectables, and dusting powders.It is absolutely vital that you use a product that is specifically labeled for the type of animal you are treating, such as cattle, goats, or pigs.The dosage must be carefully calculated based on the animal's body weight to ensure it is both effective and safe.You must read and follow all the instructions on the product label precisely.Pay close attention to the withdrawal period, which is the mandatory waiting time between treatment and when the animal's milk or meat can be consumed.Treat all animals that have been in contact with the infested one, even if they show no signs, to prevent immediate re-infestation.The animal's environment must be treated with equal importance, as this is where the parasites live and reproduce.Remove all old bedding, manure, and organic debris from pens, sheds, and shelters.Thoroughly spray the animal's living area with a recommended insecticide solution, focusing on cracks in walls, posts, and fences where parasites hide.Repeat this environmental treatment after two weeks to kill any new parasites that have hatched from eggs.For a severe infestation, a second treatment of the animal may be necessary after 2-3 weeks to break the life cycle of the parasites.Provide supportive care to heavily infested animals, as they are often anemic and stressed.Ensure they have a highly nutritious diet with adequate minerals to help them recover from blood loss.Preventing future infestations is the ultimate goal of effective management.Conduct regular health checks on your herd by closely examining the skin, especially behind the ears, under the tail, and in the udder or scrotal area.Maintain clean, dry, and uncrowded living conditions to reduce stress and parasite.

The most important action is to isolate the severely infested animal from the rest of the herd to prevent the parasites from spreading. You must then choose an appropriate parasiticide, which is a chemical specifically designed to kill these parasites. These products come in several forms, including pour-on solutions, sprays, injectables, and dusting powders. It is absolutely vital that you use a product that is specifically labeled for the type of animal you are treating, such as cattle, goats, or pigs. The dosage must be carefully calculated based on the animal's body weight to ensure it is both effective and safe. You must read and follow all the instructions on the product label precisely. Pay close attention to the withdrawal period, which is the mandatory waiting time between treatment and when the animal's milk or meat can be consumed. Treat all animals that have been in contact with the infested one, even if they show no signs, to prevent immediate re-infestation. The animal's environment must be treated with equal importance, as this is where the parasites live and reproduce. Remove all old bedding, manure, and organic debris from pens, sheds, and shelters. Thoroughly spray the animal's living area with a recommended insecticide solution, focusing on cracks in walls, posts, and fences where parasites hide. Repeat this environmental treatment after two weeks to kill any new parasites that have hatched from eggs. For a severe infestation, a second treatment of the animal may be necessary after 2-3 weeks to break the life cycle of the parasites. Provide supportive care to heavily infested animals, as they are often anemic and stressed. Ensure they have a highly nutritious diet with adequate minerals to help them recover from blood loss. Preventing future infestations is the ultimate goal of effective management. Conduct regular health checks on your herd by closely examining the skin, especially behind the ears, under the tail, and in the udder or scrotal area. Maintain clean, dry, and uncrowded living conditions to reduce stress and parasites.

Lice are smaller and harder to see; their presence is often indicated by intense itching, restlessness, and a rough, matted coat. QueryText: vaccinations of mithun
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Vaccination of Mithun
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the proper vaccination schedules of Mithun?
KccAns: mithuns can be vaccinated twice a year in interval of six months contact nearest vety officer and ask for vaccination schdule of your area do keep the mithun in home during vaccination
QueryText_normalized: vaccinations of mithun
Primary Answer (Level0): The vaccination of Mithun (Bos frontalis) is carried out mainly under the supervision of the Department of Animal Husbandry and Veterinary and in collaboration with ICAR-National Research Centre on Mithun (ICAR-NRCM). Mithun are typically vaccinated twice a year during pre-monsoon and post-monsoon seasons, and vaccinations are mainly done to prevent diseases like Foot and Mouth(FMD), Haemorrhagic Septicemia (HS), and Black Quarter(BQ). These vaccination camps are organized through the government veterinary department, along with vaccination, Mithuns are often tagged and monitored for their overall health status. Besides the government veterinary department, ICAR-NRCM regularly conducted vaccination camps and an effective disease management programme to reduce mortality rates, improve animal health, and support sustainable Mithun rearing. For detailed vaccine schedules, farmers and stakeholders are advised to consult their local veterinary offices or ICAR-NRCM authorities.

These vaccination camps are organized through the government veterinary department, along with vaccination, Mithuns are often tagged and monitored for their overall health status. Besides the government veterinary department, ICAR-NRCM regularly conducted vaccination camps and an effective disease management programme to reduce mortality rates, improve animal health, and support sustainable Mithun rearing. For detailed vaccine schedules, farmers and stakeholders are advised to consult their local veterinary offices or ICAR-NRCM authorities.

QueryText: ticks and lice infestation in yakadvice a treatment
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Suggest treatment for the ticks and lice infestation in Yak
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control ticks and lice infection in Yaks?
KccAns: for ticks take 25 ml deltametrin cyperametrin in a litre of water this dose can be used to apply on animal body to keep away the ticks and lice pouron can be applied from neck to tail region
QueryText_normalized: ticks and lice infestation in yakadvice a treatment
Primary Answer (Level0): Ticks and lice infestation in yaks can cause severe irritation, blood loss, weight loss, and reduce productivity. Proper treatment and prevention are crucial for maintaining health and productivity. Use veterinary-approved acaricides and insecticides such as pour-on formulations containing permethrin, cypermethrin, or deltamethrin applied directly to the animal's skin along with backline, and repeat treatments every 10–14 days as per product instructions, usually 2-3 rounds to break the life cycle. Use the veterinarian's recommended dose of injectable or oral ivermectin preparation, which is effective against both ticks and lice infestation in yaks. Treatment alone is often not enough to control parasitic infestations; preventive measures are also essential. Maintain cleanliness in yaks' shelter, regularly remove bedding or dung, and rotate grazing areas. It is also recommended to always consult a qualified veterinarian for selecting appropriate products and for guidance on dosage and safety to avoid chemical resistance or toxicity.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Ticks and lice infestation in yaks can cause severe irritation, blood loss, weight loss and reduce productivity. Proper treatment and prevention is crucial for maintaining the health and productivity.Veterinary-approved acaricides and insecticides, such as pour-on formulations containing permethrin, cypermethrin, or deltamethrin, can be applied directly to the animal’s skin along the backline. The frequency of re-application should strictly follow the product label, as modern formulations often provide protection for several weeks (commonly 4–8 weeks). Use veterinarian's recommended dose of injectable or oral ivermectin preparations which are effective against both ticks and lice infestation in yaks. Since ivermectin has a prolonged duration of action, repeat treatments are generally given at longer intervals (commonly 28 days or more) to avoid overdose, toxicity, and rapid resistance development. Treatment alone is often not enough to control parasitic infestations, preventive measures are also essential. Maintain cleanliness in yaks shelter, regularly remove bedding or dung, and rotate grazing areas. It is also recommended always consult with a qualified veterinarian for selecting appropriate products, and for guidance on dosage and safety to avoid chemical resistance or toxicity.

-Critical Dosing Error: The recommendation to repeat treatments every 10–14 days is a major error for systemic products. Injectable Ivermectin has a long duration of action, and re-treatment is typically performed after 28 days or more to avoid overdose, toxicity, and rapid resistance development.

Outdated Re-application Schedule: The 10-14 day interval is also incorrect for most modern pour-on products, which often provide protection for 4-8 weeks. The re-application schedule must always be based on the specific product's label instructions, not a generic rule.

QueryText: is the milk of rabies vaccinated cow be consumable by human being
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Will the milk of rabies-vaccinated cows be consumable by human beings?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Will the milk of rabies-vaccinated cows be consumable by human beings?
KccAns: yes it is consumable by thoroughly pasteurized or boil by 15-20 minutes
QueryText_normalized: is the milk of rabies vaccinated cow be consumable by human being
Primary Answer (Level0): Milk from rabies rabies-vaccinated cow is safe for human consumption. There is no scientific evidence that the rabies virus can be transmitted through the milk of vaccinated or healthy animals. According to health authorities and research, the rabies virus is not found in milk or milk products, and human rabies cases from consuming milk have not been reported. However, it is safe to ensure milk is pasteurized or boiled before consumption to eliminate any possible risks.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Milk of rabies vaccinated cow is safe for human consumption. There is no scientific evidence that rabies virus can be transmitted through the milk of vaccinated or healthy animals. According to health authorities and research, rabies virus is not found in milk or milk products, and human rabies cases from consuming milk have not been reported. However, it is safe to ensure milk is pasteurized or boiled before consumption to eliminate any possible risks. But, if a cow is vaccinated after a suspected rabid bite, its milk should not be used and must be discarded during the full observation period, which may last for several months.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Critical Clarification Needed: The advice is correct for a routine vaccination but dangerously incomplete for a post-exposure scenario. This distinction must be made clear.

Routine Annual Vaccination: If a healthy cow receives its regular, scheduled preventive vaccine, its milk is completely safe for human consumption.

Post-Exposure Vaccination (After a Bite): If a cow is vaccinated after being bitten by a potentially rabid animal, the standard veterinary protocol is to discard the milk during the entire observation period (which can last for several months). This is a critical precaution because the health status of the animal itself is unknown, even if the virus is not transmitted via milk.

QueryText: QWERRY ABOUT INTEREST RATE OF AGRI TERM LOAN
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Interest rate of agri term loan
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding the interest rate of an agri-term loan?
KccAns: told him its about 1375
QueryText_normalized: qwerry about interest rate of agri term loan
Primary Answer (Level0): Interest rates for agriculture term loans differ based on the bank, loan scheme, and amount. While it is true that you can get a loan from a bank with interest rates that vary, you must know about the special schemes that are specifically designed for farmers in your state. These schemes offer far better terms. The most important ones are the Atma Nirbhar Krishi Yojana (ANKY) for general agriculture and the Atma Nirbhar Bagwani Yojana (ANBY) for horticulture. These are "credit-linked subsidy" programs, meaning the government gives you a large subsidy directly tied to your bank loan. The funding pattern for these schemes is very favorable: the government provides a direct 45% subsidy, which you do not have to pay back. The bank provides a 45% loan, which you will need to repay. And your own contribution, or "margin money," is only 10% of the total project cost. This means a massive 90% of your project is funded by the government and the bank, making it much easier for you to start or expand your business. For smaller, short-term expenses like crop loans or Kisan Credit Cards (KCC), the state government also offers the Chief Minister's Krishi Rinn Yojana (CMKRY). Under this scheme, if you take a loan up to ₹3 lakh and repay it on time, the interest rate can be effectively zero percent due to an interest subvention from both the state and central governments. For more information do contact your nearest bank branch.

QueryText: ASKED ABOUT CARP CULTURE
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding Carp culture
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the recommended fish species and techniques for Fish farming?
KccAns: given him in details
QueryText_normalized: asked about carp culture
Primary Answer (Level0): In your region,  fish farming is completely carp centric. In medium altitude areas( up to 3500 ft) the popular and recommended fish culture are, Indian Major Carp(Catla, Rohu and Mrigal), and exotic carp(Silver carp, Grass carp and common carp). For higher altitude areas(more than 3500 ft) cold water species are recommended such as Grass carp, Silver carp, Trout, Mahseer, Snow trout and Common carp. Interested farmers can grow fish through composite fish culture technique or integrated farming. In composite fish culture technique, different compatible species with complementary feeding habits are develop together in a Pond . Integrated farming such as paddy cum fish farming(rearing fish in rice field), duck cum fish farming or pig cum fish farming(using livestock waste as natural fertilizer, no need to apply external fertilizer) also popular. For successful composite carp culture, prepare ponds with 1.5 to 2.0 meters depth, provide with an inlet and outlet for water management, clear weeds from pond, and add lime and manure to maintain water quality and fertility. The recommended stocking density is 2400-4000  fingerlings/acre with a species ratio of Catla 30%, Rohu 30%, Mrigal 20%, Grass carp 10%, Silver carp 5% and Common carp 5%,  provide supplementary feed mixture of mustard cake and rice bran daily to ensure healthy growth of fishes.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Arunachal Pradesh fish farming is completely carp centric. In medium altitude areas( up to 3500 ft) the popular and recommended fish culture are, Indian Major Carp(Catla, Rohu and Mrigal), and exotic carp(Silver carp, Grass carp and common carp). For higher altitude areas(more than 3500 ft) cold water species are recommended such as Grass carp, Silver carp, Trout, Mahseer, Snow trout and Common carp. Integrated farming such as paddy cum fish farming(rearing fish in rice field), duck cum fish farming or pig cum fish farming(using livestock waste as natural fertilizer, no need to apply external fertilizer) also popular. For successful composite carp culture, prepare ponds with 1.5 to 2.0 meters depth, provide with an inlet and outlet for water management, clear weeds from pond, and add lime and manure to maintain water quality and fertility. The recommended stocking density is 6,000–8,000 fingerlings/ha with a species ratio of Catla 30%, Rohu 30%, Mrigal 20%, Grass carp 10%, Silver carp 5% and Common carp 5%,  provide supplementary feed mixture of mustard cake and rice bran daily to ensure healthy growth of fishes.

For successful composite carp culture, prepare ponds with 1.5 to 2.0 meters, provide an inlet and outlet for water management, clear weeds from the pond, and add lime and manure to maintain water quality and fertility. The recommended stocking density is 2400-4000 fingerlings/acre with a species ratio of Catla 30%, Rohu 30%, Mrigal 20%, Grass carp 10%, Silver carp 5% and Common carp 5%. Provide a supplementary feed mixture of mustard cake and rice bran daily to ensure the healthy growth of fish.

QueryText: ASKING FOR THE CORRECTION OF SLOW GROWTH OF FISH
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Correction for slow growth of fish
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the causes of slow growth in Fish, and how can I correct it?
KccAns: i transfer the call to fishery expert
QueryText_normalized: asking for the measure of slow growth of fish
Primary Answer (Level0): Slow growth of fish is due to several reasons, such as poor water quality, nutritional deficiencies, overstocking of fish in a pond, inadequate feeding, poor quality fingerlings, and cold water in hill conditions. To correct this, ensure adequate oxygen by using aerators or fountain especially during early morning hours, regularly check the pH of pond water, if it is acidic apply lime to the pond bottom during off season, provide nutritionally balance feed with protein level(25-35%) suitable for fish species, maintain proper pond hygiene by removing organic matter, and control weed growth in pond. Use fast-growing and locally adapted fish species or improved breeds such as Indian major carps (rohu, catla, mrigal), avoid overstocking of fish, and maintain 6000 to 8000 fingerlings per acre. and procure fingerlings from certified hatcheries. Regularly observe your fish for any signs of disease, such as sores, lesions, or abnormal behaviour, and use a salt bath according to the local fishery extension officer's recommendation to control external parasites. Apply a feed mixture of rice bran + mustard oil cake (1:1 ratio) @ 2–3% of fish biomass/day and consult with local fishery extension expert and KVKs.

QueryText: asking about the treatment of diarrhoea in a broiller farm
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Treatment of Diarrhea in a Broiler farm
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to treat diarrhoea in Broiler farm?
KccAns: suggested to administer enrox 2ml per litre of water
QueryText_normalized: asking about the treatment of diarrhoea in a broiller farm
Primary Answer (Level0): Diarrhoea is a symptom, not a disease. Before you can treat diarrhoea, it is important to identify the actual cause of it. Diarrhoea in a broiler can be caused by various factors such as bacterial infection (E. coli, Salmonella, Clostridium ), viral infections (rotavirus, reovirus), Coccidiosis, improper feed or water quality, stress, or antibiotics misuse. If a high proportion of the flock is affected, or if the affected birds show other symptoms like lethargy, loss of appetite, or bloody droppings, it is crucial to consult a veterinarian immediately. To control or prevent this, separate sick birds to prevent spread, clean and disinfect the poultry house feeders and drinkers, ensure birds have a fresh, clean drinking water source, and supplement water with oral rehydration salts or electrolyte solutions to combat dehydration. If diarrhoea is caused by bacterial (e.g., E. coli or Salmonella), a veterinarian may prescribe an antibiotic like Neomycin, Tylosin, Chlortetracycline, Furazolidone or Sulfadimidine(use veterinarian-recommended dose), and if the diarrhoea is caused by coccidiosis, an anticoccidial medication such as amprolium or sulfa drugs may be necessary. Besides this, ensure good quality feeds with probiotics or prebiotics and vaccinated broilers as per the vaccine schedule to prevent enteric diseases. Always consult a veterinarian before using any medication for correct diagnosis and specific treatment according to your farm, and also, overuse of antibiotics can lead to drug resistance, which is a major problem in poultry farming.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Diarrhoea is a symptom, not a disease. Before you can treat diarrhoea it is important to identify the actual cause of it. Diarrhoea in a broiler can caused from various factor such as,  bacterial infection (E. coli, Salmonella, Clostridium ), viral infections (rotavirus, reovirus), Coccidiosis, improper feed or water quality, stress, or antibiotics misuse. To control or prevent this, separate sick birds to prevent spread, clean and disinfect the poultry house feeders and drinkers, ensure birds have fresh, clean drinking water source, and supplement a mixture of common salt (1 g/L) and sugar/jaggery (10 g/L) in clean drinking water to combat dehydration. If diarrhoea is caused by bacterial (e.g., E. coli or Salmonella), veterinarian may prescribe antibiotic like Neomycin, Tylosin, Chlortetracycline, or Sulfadimidine(use veterinarian recommended dose) and if the diarrhoea is caused by coccidiosis, an anticoccidial medication such as amprolium or sulfa drugs may be necessary. Beside this ensure good quality feeds with probiotics or prebiotic and vaccinated broilers as per vaccine schedule to prevent enteric diseases. Always consult a veterinarian before using any medication for correct diagnosis and specific treatment according to your farm and also overuse of antibiotics can lead to drug resistance, which is a major problem in poultry farming.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Critical Safety & Legal Error: The text lists Furazolidone as a potential treatment. This is a major error, as Furazolidone is a banned antibiotic for use in food-producing animals (including poultry) in India due to human health concerns and must be removed from the list.

Missing Practical Detail: For practical advice, a simple homemade electrolyte solution can be recommended for rehydration: a mixture of common salt (1 g/L) and sugar/jaggery (10 g/L) in clean drinking water.

QueryText: SLOW GROWTH IN VANARAJA
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Slow growth in Vanraj
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the causes of slow growth of Vanraja poultry birds and how can I correct it?
KccAns: advice to give 1ambiplex 4 ml for 15 birds with water with water
QueryText_normalized: slow growth in vanaraja
Primary Answer (Level0): Vanraja is a dual-purpose poultry breed known for its fast growth and good egg-laying capacity. Vanraja chicken may experience slow growth due to several reasons, such as poor nutrition, inadequate feed, poor feeding quality, inadequate water supply, poor management, and disease infection(Newcastle Disease, Coccidiosis, and Fowl Pox). For the first 6 to 8 weeks provide complete balanced feeds that contain necessary protein, energy and micronutrients, supplement 15% fresh azolla with locally available feed ingredients, supplement the birds diet with grains like maize, bajra or rice bran @ 25-50 grams per bird per day, ensure continuous access to fresh water, and monitor growth weekly and adjust feeds accordingly. Maintain correct brooder temperature(for a day old chicks, the ideal temperature will be around 32-33°C and gradually decrease by about 2°C each week until at around 26°C), avoid overcrowding, maintain pa roper vaccination schedule as recommended by a veterinarian to prevent Newcastle and Fowl pox disease, and regularly deworm the birds, especially if they are free-range. Always consult with a veterinarian for proper suggestions and guidance.

Always consult with a veterinarian for proper suggestion and guidance.
Comment (Reviewer1): Critical Feeding Error: The advice to supplement a "complete balanced feed" with extra grains (maize, bajra) is a major error. This practice unbalances the diet by lowering the crucial protein-to-energy ratio, which will lead to slower growth and nutritional deficiencies, not faster growth.

QueryText: ASKING ABOUT LAYER FARMING
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding Layer farming
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is Layer farming and how to do?
KccAns: explain in details about layer farming
QueryText_normalized: asking about layer farming
Primary Answer (Level0): Layer farming is the practice of raising hens for egg production, and is a significant and growing sector in the Poultry industry. Layer farming is a profitable venture in Arunachal Pradesh because of high demand for eggs, and the humid subtropical climate in the valleys and foothills of Arunachal Pradesh is generally suitable for poultry farming. Choose a location with good drainage, a reliable water supply, adequate space for poultry sheds, and maintain proper insulation and ventilation to protect from cold. If you want to start layer farming, set up a poultry farm, small to medium size farm is suitable for 500-2000 birds, essential infrastructure like proper nesting boxes, feeders, drinkers are required,  and commercial breed like Vanaraja, Rhode Island Red, BV-300(white eggs), BV-380(brown eggs) and White Leghorn are popular for egg production. Provide balanced feed formulated (16-18 % protein and calcium) to meet the nutritional requirementss of layers, maintain optimum temperature (18-24°C) and lighting schedule(16 hours of light per day) to stimulate egg laying, and maintaia n a proper vaccination schedule according to the veterinarian recommendation to prevent Ranikhet (Newcastle disease) and infectious bursal disease (Gumboro). With proper management, layer farming (egg production) can provide a steady income. The Arunachal Pradesh government and NABARD provide subsidies for poultry farmers. Farmers interested in layer farming can contact the local animal husbandry office or KVK for training..

QueryText: information regarding diseases of chilli
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding the diseases of Chilli
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control diseases in Chilli?
KccAns: spray malathion 50 ec 2ml litre water
QueryText_normalized: desease
Primary Answer (Level0): In Arunachal Pradesh, chilli is an important cash crop, but farmers often face losses due to major diseases if timely protection measures are not taken. The three most serious diseases of chilli reported in the region are Anthracnose/Fruit Rot (Colletotrichum capsici), Powdery Mildew (Leveillula taurica), and Leaf Curl Disease (caused by Chilli Leaf Curl Virus, transmitted by whitefly). For Anthracnose, you should use disease-free seed and treat seeds with Thiram 75 WP at 2-3 g/kg of seed before sowing. Field sanitation, crop rotation, and destruction of infected fruits are important. On disease appearance in standing crop, spray Mancozeb 75 WP at 600-800 g/acre or Propiconazole 25 EC at 200 ml/acre, repeated at 10–15 days interval if needed. For Powdery Mildew, which spreads quickly in warm and humid weather, ensure proper plant spacing and avoid excess nitrogen. On symptoms in standing crop, spray Wettable Sulphur 80 WP at 1.25-1.3 kg/acre or Hexaconazole 5 EC at 200 ml/acre, repeated after 10–12 days if disease persists. For Leaf Curl Virus, there is no direct chemical cure, so management focuses on controlling the vector whitefly. Use resistant varieties where available, remove and destroy infected plants early, and control whitefly by spraying Neem Oil 10,000 ppm (5 ml per litre of water or 1 litre/acre) or chemical insecticides like Thiamethoxam 25 WG at 40 g/acre or Imidacloprid 17.8 SL at 60-80 ml/acre, ensuring thorough coverage of the underside of leaves. Install yellow sticky traps (6–8 per acre) and maintain field sanitation to further reduce the spread. In chilli cultivation, you must always observe the Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) to ensure the produce is safe for consumption and free from harmful residues. PHI of Mancozeb 75 WP requires at least 7 days before harvest, while Propiconazole 25 EC and Hexaconazole 5 EC need a longer interval of about 14 days. Wettable Sulphur 80 WP has a shorter waiting period of around 5 days, making it safer for use closer to harvest. Among insecticides, both Thiamethoxam 25 WG and Imidacloprid 17.8 SL should not be sprayed within 7 days of harvest.

QueryText: ASKING ABOUT THE TREATMENT OF BLINDNESS IN A POULTRY FARM
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Treatment of blindness in Poultry
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to treat Poultry blindness?
KccAns: suggested to administer ambiplex syrup 2mllit of water
QueryText_normalized: asking about the treatment of blindness in a poultry farm
Primary Answer (Level0): Blindness is a symptom, not a disease. The probable causes of blindness in poultry are nutritional deficiency(lack of vitamin A), external eye injuries from foreign bodies, or disease infection(such as infectious coryza, IBD disease, Marek disease, and fowl pox). If blindness is due to vitamin A deficiency, immediately supplement Vitamin A through feed or water as prescribed by a veterinarian. Infectious diseases like infectious  Marek disease and fowl pox can cause blindness in poultry, to prevent this vaccination according to veterinarian is mandatory. Infectious coryza disease also causes blindness. To control this, isolate infected birds and use antibiotics as per the veterinarian's recommendation. If you notice any blind symptoms in your farm,  immediately consult with a veterinarian because early diagnosis can prevent the spread and effectively manage the symptoms.

QueryText: fishery related quarry
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding Fishery
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding Fishery?
KccAns: transfer to fishery expert
QueryText_normalized: fishery related quarry
Primary Answer (Level0): Fish farming is a great way to earn a living in Arunachal Pradesh due to our rich water resources. The most popular and suitable fish for farming in our state fall into two main categories based on our varied climate and altitude. In the lower and middle-altitude regions (below 1,000 meters), which have warmer temperatures, farmers commonly raise Indian Major Carps (IMCs) like Rohu, Catla, and Mrigal, as well as exotic carps like Common Carp, Grass Carp, and Silver Carp.  These fish are fast-growing and are well-suited for traditional composite fish culture, where different species are raised together to utilize all layers of the pond. For the higher-altitude regions (above 1,200 meters), with their cold, fast-flowing streams and lakes, coldwater species are more suitable. The most popular fish in these areas are trout, especially Rainbow Trout and Brown Trout, and our indigenous Golden Mahseer. These cold-water species fetch a high market price, making their cultivation very profitable.

QueryText: ASKING ABOUT GOOD BREED OF GOAT
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Good breeds of Goat
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Which Goat breeds are suitable for rearing?
KccAns: suggested to contact with nearest veterinary dyspensary
QueryText_normalized: asking about good breed of goat
Primary Answer (Level0): Choosing the right goat breed is essential for successful and profitable farming. The recommended goat breeds are: Black Bengal Goat(well adapted to hilly terrains and fluctuating temperatures, resistance to many common diseases and high quality meat), Assam Hill Goat(hardy, able to survive with minimal resources and suitable for hilly, forest grazing system), Jamunapari ( large size with high milk production), Sirohi(disease resistant and withstand hard weather) and Beetal goat(large size, dual purpose breed).

QueryText: oxygen deplition in fish pond
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Oxygen depletion in Fish pond
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to avoid oxygen depletion in Fishpond?
KccAns: adviced to use o2max
QueryText_normalized: oxygen deplition in fish pond
Primary Answer (Level0): Oxygen depletion in a fish pond occurs when the oxygen demands exceed the supply, leading to low dissolved oxygen levels that can stress and kill fish. The reason for oxygen depletion in the field may be due to high water temperature, over-fertilization, excessive organic matter in water, sudden death of a large number of algae, water stratification, and lack of water circulation. In oxygen-deprived ponds, fish stop eating and gulping for air at the water surface near the pond's edge, with water colour changes from blue/green to grayish, brown, or black. To correct oxygen depletion, immediately aerate the ponds using pumps, paddle wheels, or aerators, which help in circulating oxygen throughout the ponds and stop feeding to reduce the oxygen demand on waste and uneaten food. To prevent this, control excessive algae and aquatic vegetation growth, remove organic debris, and avoid overfeeding, stock algae-eating fish like grass carp, provide shade to reduce water temperature, and monitor dissolved oxygen levels in early mornings and hot weather to detect problems early.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Oxygen depletion in fish pond occurs when the demands for oxygen exceeds the supply, leading to low dissolve oxygen levels that can stress and kill fish. The reason of oxygen depletion in field may be due to high water temperature, over-fertilization, excessive organic matter in water, sudden death of large number of algae, water stratification and lack of water circulation. In Oxygen depleted ponds, fish are stop eating and gulping for air at water surfaces near the pond's edge with water colour changes from blue/green to grayish, brown, or black. To correct oxygen depletion, immediately aerate the ponds using pumps, paddle wheels or aerators which help in circulating oxygen throughout the ponds, broadcast Potassium Permanganate (KMnO₄) @ 2–5 kg/acre  to quickly increase dissolved oxygen levels, and feeding should be stop temporarily to reduce the oxygen demand on waste and uneaten food. To prevent this, control excessive algae and aquatic vegetation growth, remove organic debris and avoid overfeeding, stock algae eating fish like grass carp, provide shade to reduce water temperature and monitor dissolved oxygen levels in early mornings and hot weather to detect problem early.

For immediate, life-saving intervention, a chemical aerator should be used. The standard recommendation is to broadcast Potassium Permanganate (KMnO₄) @ 2-5 kg/acre to rapidly increase dissolved oxygen levels.

QueryText: ASKING ABOUT THE IBD VACCINATION SCHEDULE IN POULTRY
Refined KCC Query [HF]: IBD vaccination schedule in Poultry
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the proper IBD vaccination schedule of Poultry?
KccAns: explain in details about the vaccinartion schedule in poultry
QueryText_normalized: asking about the ibd vaccination schedule in poultry
Primary Answer (Level0): The infectious Bursal Disease(IBD), also known as Gumboro disease, is a highly contagious viral disease in commercial broiler and layer chickens. A proper vaccination schedule is essential to prevent the disease. The IBD (Infectious Bursal Disease) vaccination schedule for poultry in Arunachal Pradesh varies according to the type of birds being raised, with broiler chickens receiving their first IBD vaccination at 7-9 days of age via intraocular route or drinking water, followed by a booster dose at 16-18 days through drinking water or alternatively first at 14 days via intraocular or intranasal route and second IBD booster at 28 day via drinking water. Layer birds follow a slightly different schedule, with the first IBD vaccination given at 14-16 days via intraocular or drinking water route, and a booster dose given at 24-26 days through drinking water. Backyard poultry, including Vanraja and indigenous breeds, receive Gumboro (IBD) vaccine as one drop via the eye route on the 7th day, followed by a booster dose as one drop orally on the 14th day. Always consult with a qualified poultry veterinarian from the state's Animal Husbandry department or a private practitioner; they can suggest a proper IBD vaccination schedule based on your specific farm's risk factors and the prevalence of IBD in your locality. Ensure the vaccines are stored and transported correctly at  (2-8°C), vaccinate the birds at a time when they are not under stress from heat and cold, and for drinking water administration, ensure that water is free from chlorine and disinfectants.

QueryText: ASKING ABOUT THE VARIOUS SCHEME OF FISHERIES
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Various schemes of fisheries
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Which Fishery schemes are available?
KccAns: given in details about the various schemes
QueryText_normalized: asking about the various centralyy scheme of fisheries
Primary Answer (Level0): The government of India, along with the Department of Fisheries of the Arunachal Pradesh government, has launched several central and state-sponsored schemes on fisheries to boost the fisheries sector across the State. Under the Pradhan Mantri Matsya Sampada Yojana(PMMSY) scheme, subsidies are provided for the construction of new fish ponds, especially for the composite fish and carp culture, provide financial assistance for the establishment of fish hatcheries, and promote paddy cum fish culture and piggery cum fish farming, which are profitable for farmers. Atma Nirbhar Matsya Palan Yojana(ANMPY) by the Arunachal Pradesh government provides benefits to farmers, SHGs for fish pond construction and aquaculture activities. Under this scheme, a 45% subsidy, 45% bank loan, and 10% beneficiary contribution, with collateral-free loans up to Rs. 1.6 lakh for individuals and Rs. 10 lakh for SHGs are provided. Farmers in Arunachal Pradesh who want to avail benefits or seek assistance from these schemes can contact the District Fishery Office and the local Krishi Vigyan Kendra.

QueryText: WANTED TO REGISTER HIMSELF IN KCC
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How do I register in KCC?

Primary Answer (Level0): The process to apply for a Kisan Credit Card is quite straightforward. The best way to get started is to visit a bank branch near you. This could be the Arunachal Pradesh Rural Bank (APRB), State Bank of India (SBI), or any other commercial bank. They all offer the Kisan Credit Card and are familiar with the process. You can get the application form directly from the bank branch. You will need a copy of your Aadhaar Card and PAN Card, or any other valid ID proof like a Voter ID or Driving License. A few recent passport-sized photographs are required for the application form. Most importantly, you need proof of your land ownership. In Arunachal Pradesh, a Land Holding Certificate issued by the concerned Circle Officer (CO), Block Development Officer (BDO), or ADC/DC office is accepted. The Circle Officer will also certify that you are in possession of the land. Most importantly, you need proof of your land ownership. In Arunachal Pradesh, a Land Holding Certificate issued by the concerned Circle Officer (CO), Block Development Officer (BDO), or ADC/DC office is accepted. The Circle Officer will also certify that you are in possession of the land. You can also apply for the KCC online through the official portals of banks like SBI or Union Bank of India, but for a farmer in your region, it is often more comfortable and effective to go to the bank branch in person. The bank officials will guide you through the process, help you fill out the forms correctly, and ensure you get all the benefits available under the government schemes.

QueryText: asking about qual bird
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information about Quail bird
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Can you give some information about the Quail bird?
KccAns: describe in details
QueryText_normalized: asking about qual bird
Primary Answer (Level0): Quail bird is also known as Bater bird in many parts of India. In Arunachal Pardesh there are 3 common species of bater 1. Rain Quail (Coturnix coromandelica) 2. Manipur Bush Quail (Perdicula manipurensis) 3. Jungle Bush Quail (Perdicula asiatica). Quails are small pulmp ground dwelling birds. Quails are known for being very secretive and are more often heard than seen. They are omniverse, feeding on a variety of seeds, grains, leaves, and insects. In India hunting the most wild quails  is illegal due to conservation concerns. They are often raised in captivity for food and eggs. Which are considered a delicacy.

QueryText: ASKING ABOUT LAMENESS IN POULTRY
Refined KCC Query [HF]: What is Lameness in poultry?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the lameness in poultry?
KccAns: suggested to administer ambiplex twice daily by mixing with water
QueryText_normalized: asking about lameness in poultry
Primary Answer (Level0): Lameness in poultry refers to any condition that impairs the ability to walk or move normally. It is common in fast growing boiler chickens, as their skeletal system may struggle to keep up with rapid muscle and body weight development. It can happens due to genetic factor, Nutritional deficiencies such as Calcium, phosphorus, and Vitamin D, various bacteria and viruses can cause lameness, environmental and poor management also cause lameness such as poor litter quality, overcrowding. Controlling lameness requires a comprehensive multi approach such as work with a breeder who focuses on balancing rapid growth with the development of strong, healthy skeletal structure. Ensure proper balanced diet with adequate levels of calcium, phosphorus and vitamin D, supplement the feed with other essentials nutrients like biotin and choline if necessary. Follow proper vaccination schedule as recommended by a veterinarian to prevent viral diseases that cause lameness. Keep the litter dry loose, and clean to prevent footpad issues, ensure proper ventilation to remove moisture. Avoid over crowding, provide sufficient space for birds to move around comfortably without causing physical stress. Thoroughly clean and disinfect the sheds and all equipment between flocks.

QueryText: information regarding ginger
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding Ginger cultivation
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding Ginger cultivation?
KccAns: call transferred to expert for further consultation
QueryText_normalized: agrilquery
Primary Answer (Level0): Ginger is one of the most important spice crops grown in Arunachal Pradesh and it is well suited to the state’s hilly climate and fertile soils. Ginger grows best in well-drained loamy soil rich in organic matter and under partial shade with good rainfall. Farmers usually plant ginger during April–May with the onset of pre-monsoon showers. In Arunachal Pradesh, popular high-yielding varieties include Nadia, Suprabha, Suruchi, Suravi, Varada, IISR Mahima, and IISR Rejatha. These varieties are not only high yielding but also have good rhizome quality and higher recovery of dry ginger and oil content. The average yield under good management practices is about 70–90 quintals per acre, while improved varieties like Varada and IISR Mahima can give up to 100–120 quintals per acre in the region. For sowing, use rhizome seed pieces weighing 20–25 g each, at a seed rate of about 5–6 quintals per acre. Use only healthy, disease-free rhizomes. Before planting, treat the rhizomes with Mancozeb at 3 g/kg of rhizomes by dipping them for 30 minutes and drying them in the shade. Alternatively, you can use Trichoderma viride at 5–10 g/kg as a biological seed treatment to prevent fungal diseases. Maintain adequate mulching for moisture conservation, and provide regular weeding and earthing-up.

Ginger grows best in well-drained loamy soil rich in organic matter and under partial shade with good rainfall. Farmers usually plant ginger during April–May with the onset of pre-monsoon showers. Popular high-yielding varieties include Nadia, Suprabha, Suruchi, Suravi, Varada, IISR Mahima, and IISR Rejatha. These varieties are not only high yielding but also have good rhizome quality and higher recovery of dry ginger and oil content. The average yield under good management practices is about 70–90 quintals per acre, while improved varieties like Varada and IISR Mahima can give up to 100–120 quintals per acre in the region. For sowing, use rhizome seed pieces weighing 20–25 g each, at a seed rate of about 5–6 quintals per acre. Use only healthy, disease-free rhizomes. Before planting, treat the rhizomes with Mancozeb at 3 g/kg of rhizomes by dipping them for 30 minutes and drying them in the shade. Alternatively, you can use Trichoderma viride at 5–10 g/kg as a biological seed treatment to prevent fungal diseases. Maintain adequate mulching for moisture conservation, and provide regular weeding and earthing-up.

QueryText: ASKING ABOUT HEAT STRESS IN POULTRY
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding heat stress in poultry
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control heat stress in poultry?
KccAns: suggested to adminiter electrocare powder by mixing with water daily
QueryText_normalized: asking about heat stress in poultry
Primary Answer (Level0): Heat stress in poultry is a major challenge, especially in regions with hot climates. It occurs when a bird's body is unable to maintain a balance between the heat it produces and the heat it loses to the environment. Unlike mammals, chickens and other poultry do not have sweat glands, so they must rely on different mechanisms to cool themselves. A bird's body temperature is normally around 41-42°C (106-108°F). The "thermoneutral zone" where they are most comfortable is typically between 18-21°C. When the ambient temperature rises above this zone, the bird's thermoregulatory mechanisms are overwhelmed. The primary factors contributing to heat stress are high ambient temperature and high humidity. Direct sunlight or heat from the surrounding environment (e.g., a hot roof or floor) also adds to the heat load. Fast-growing broiler chickens have a high metabolic rate, which generates a large amount of internal body heat. This makes them particularly susceptible to heat stress. Heat stress has a wide range of negative impacts on poultry, affecting their health, welfare, and productivity, such as the most common sign. Birds open their mouths and breathe rapidly to lose heat through evaporation. This can lead to respiratory alkalosis (an imbalance in blood pH) due to excessive carbon dioxide loss. Birds hold their wings away from their bodies to increase surface area and allow for heat dissipation. They become lethargic and spend more time resting. Broilers may experience a significant drop in body weight gain due to reduced feed consumption. Heat stress can suppress the birds' immune system, making them more susceptible to infectious diseases. Meat quality can be affected, leading to reduced water-holding capacity and changes in color and texture. Managing heat stress requires a proactive approach that combines proper housing, feeding, and water management, such as ensuring excellent air circulation at the bird level to remove heat and humidity. This can be achieved with fans. Use evaporative cooling systems like foggers, misting systems, or cool pads to lower the ambient temperature, especially in the hottest hours. Insulate the roof and walls to prevent solar heat gain. Reduce the stocking density to give birds more room to move and dissipate heat. Ensure Ample, Cool Water: Provide easy access to a sufficient number of waterers. Regularly flush water lines to ensure the water is fresh and cool. Add electrolytes to the drinking water. This helps replenish minerals lost during panting and maintains the bird's hydration and acid-base balance. Feed birds during the cooler parts of the day (early morning and late evening/night). This encourages them to eat when they are less stressed. Formulate a diet that is more nutrient-dense to compensate for reduced feed intake. Supplement the feed or water with vitamins (especially A, D, E, and C), minerals (like zinc and chromium), and other additives that can help reduce oxidative stress and support the immune system.

QueryText: ASKING ABOUT THE TREATMENT OF WHITE DIARRHOEA OF A BROILLER FARM
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Treatment of White Diarrhea at a broiler farm
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the treatment for white diarrhea in a broiler farm?
KccAns: suggested to apply the sulcoprim pow 5gm5lit of water
QueryText_normalized: asking about the treatment of white diarrhoea of a broiller farm
Primary Answer (Level0): White diarrhea in poultry, particularly in young broiler chicks, is a common and serious symptom that can indicate several underlying diseases. The most notable cause is Pullorum Disease, a highly contagious bacterial infection. However, other conditions, such as Coccidiosis and even simple chilling, can also cause white, watery droppings. Before you can treat the condition, it's crucial to identify the root cause. A veterinarian or a poultry health expert can perform a proper diagnosis through laboratory tests. Pullorum Disease (Bacillary White Diarrhea): Caused by the bacterium Salmonella pullorum. This is a highly infectious disease that is transmitted from the hen to the chick through the egg. It can cause high mortality rates (80-100%) in chicks. Coccidiosis: Caused by a protozoan parasite, Eimeria. While coccidiosis often causes bloody or orange-colored diarrhea, some forms can present with white, watery droppings. Chilling, poor feed quality, or other bacterial infections can also result in white diarrhea. The treatment approach depends entirely on the cause. It is essential to consult with a veterinarian before administering any medication, as using the wrong drug can be ineffective and contribute to antibiotic resistance. Treatment for Pullorum Disease: While some antibiotics (such as furazolidone, chloramphenicol, and others) can reduce mortality, they are generally not recommended as a primary treatment. This is because the goal is not to "cure" the birds but to eradicate the disease from the flock. The standard and most effective method for controlling Pullorum Disease is to depopulate the infected flock. This is because birds that survive the infection will become "carriers" and continue to spread the bacteria to other birds, especially through their eggs, making the problem chronic. A strict biosecurity protocol is the most important measure to prevent Pullorum. This includes: Sourcing chicks from hatcheries certified to be Pullorum-free, testing breeding flocks for the presence of the bacteria, strict hygiene, and disinfection of all equipment and houses. Treatment for Coccidiosis: If coccidiosis is the cause, specific anticoccidial drugs (like amprolium or sulfa drugs) are administered through drinking water. Provide electrolytes and multivitamins in the water to help the birds recover from dehydration and to support their immune systems. Coccidiosis is often a result of poor hygiene. Keeping the litter dry and clean is crucial for preventing and controlling outbreaks. Regardless of the specific cause, the following management practices are crucial for both treatment and prevention of white diarrhea: As soon as you see a bird with white diarrhea, isolate it from the rest of the flock to prevent the spread of the disease. Provide fresh, clean drinking water at all times. Maintain dry, clean litter. Wet litter is a breeding ground for bacteria and parasites. Ensure the birds are receiving a high-quality, balanced feed appropriate for their age. The most important step is to consult a qualified veterinarian. They can accurately diagnose the problem and recommend the correct course of action, which may include medication, supportive therapy, or culling.

Comment (Reviewer1): Critical Safety & Legal Error: The text mentions Furazolidone and Chloramphenicol as potential antibiotics. This is a major error, as both are strictly banned for use in poultry in India due to severe human health risks. They must be removed from the text entirely to avoid dangerous misinformation.

It is essential to consult with a veterinarian before administering any medication, as using the wrong drug can be ineffective and contribute to antibiotic resistance. Treatment for Pullorum Disease: While some antibiotics can reduce mortality, they are generally not recommended as a primary treatment. This is because the goal is not to "cure" the birds but to eradicate the disease from the flock. The standard and most effective method for controlling Pullorum Disease is to depopulate the infected flock. This is because birds that survive the infection will become "carriers" and continue to spread the bacteria to other birds, especially through their eggs, making the problem chronic. A strict biosecurity protocol is the most important measure to prevent Pullorum. This includes: Sourcing chicks from hatcheries certified to be Pullorum-free, testing breeding flocks for the presence of the bacteria, strict hygiene, and disinfection of all equipment and houses. Treatment for Coccidiosis: If coccidiosis is the cause, specific anticoccidial drugs (like amprolium or sulfa drugs) are administered through drinking water. Provide electrolytes and multivitamins in the water to help the birds recover from dehydration and to support their immune systems. Coccidiosis is often a result of poor hygiene. Keeping the litter dry and clean is crucial for preventing and controlling outbreaks. Regardless of the specific cause, the following management practices are crucial for both treatment and prevention of white diarrhea: As soon as you see a bird with white diarrhea, isolate it from the rest of the flock to prevent the spread of the disease. Provide fresh, clean drinking water at all times. Maintain dry, clean litter. Wet litter is a breeding ground for bacteria and parasites. Ensure the birds are receiving a high-quality, balanced feed appropriate for their age. The most important step is to consult a qualified veterinarian. They can accurately diagnose the problem and recommend the correct course of action, which may include medication, supportive therapy, or culling.

QueryText: PACKAGE OF PRACTICE
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Package of practice for Paddy
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Package of practice for Paddy?
KccAns: explained in details
QueryText_normalized: package of practice
Primary Answer (Level0): Paddy is the most important staple food crop of Arunachal Pradesh, and because of the state’s rainfall pattern and hilly climate, farmers cultivate different types of rice depending on the season. The three major types of rice grown are Ahu, Boro, and Sali rice. Ahu Rice (Pre-monsoon Rice) is the early rice grown during March to June in upland and midland areas, using pre-monsoon showers. It matures early and provides food before the main season crop. Popular varieties are RCPL 1-10, RCM 9, and Naveen, giving an average yield of 12–15 quintals/acre. Boro Rice (Winter Rice) is grown in November to May in areas where irrigation is available, especially in valleys and low-lying fields. It is transplanted in December–January and harvested in April–May. Suitable varieties include Bahadur, Pooja, and CAU-R1, with yields of about 15–18 quintals/acre. Sali Rice (Kharif/Main Season Rice) is the major rice crop, grown during the monsoon season (June–November) under rainfed lowland and irrigated conditions. It is transplanted in July–August and harvested in October–November. High-yielding varieties recommended for Sali season are RCM 10, RCM 11, RCM 13, Luit, Rajalaxmi which can yield 18–22 quintals/acre. You should prepare your field thoroughly by ploughing and puddling it 3-4 times. This creates a soft mud that is ideal for transplanting seedlings and also helps to control weeds. For better growth, apply FYM/compost at 4–5 tonnes per acre before puddling. For cultivation of paddy in upland use 79 kg urea, 348 kg Single Superphosphate (SSP) and 49 kg Muriate of Potash (MOP) in per acre area.  For cultivation of paddy in lowland and hilly region use 88 kg urea , 348 kg Single Superphosphate (SSP) and 49 kg Muriate of Potash (MOP) in per acre area. For nursery raising, about 20–25 kg of seed per acre is sufficient. Seeds should be treated with Mancozeb 75 WP at 2.5–3 g/kg of seed before sowing to protect against seed-borne diseases. Seedlings of 20–25 days age are ideal for transplanting in puddled fields, keeping a spacing of 20 x 15 cm for better tillering and weed management.
